subdebateinfo.title: Days and Hours of Meeting and Routine of Business

subdebate.1.para: (a) the hours of meeting shall be 12.30 pm to 6.30 pm and 7.30 pm to 11.40 pm;
(b) the routine of business from 12.30 pm to 2 pm and from 7.30 pm to 11 pm shall be government business only; and
(c) the question for the adjournment of the Senate shall be proposed at 11 pm.

talk.start.para: —We have a motion before us in relation to the sitting hours of the Senate which, of course, has been a particularly contentious issue in the chamber this week. Senators will recall a debate held earlier in the week about the sitting hours for Tuesday of this week when the opposition agreed, on a no divisions and no quorum basis, to extend the sitting hours for that Tuesday to both morning and evening sittings for the Senate because we do acknowledge that there is a considerable legislative program for the Senate to give consideration to.

speech.para: The situation now is that we realise that the Manager of Government Business at that time had not fully and adequately consulted all parties and all senators in the chamber. There were very serious concerns expressed by Democrat senators about sitting Tuesday morning of this week because of the clash of those sitting times with the Democrats' party room meeting.

I have made consistently clear in the chamber over a long period of time my view that we have to acknowledge the fact that party meetings take place. As the Labor Party does not have a party meeting on a Tuesday morning—in other words, federal parlia mentary Labor Party caucus does not meet when the House of Representatives is not sitting in Canberra—there is no impediment from the point of view of a Labor Party meeting. I understand there is a similar circumstance on Tuesday for the government parties. However, we were informed only when this matter was being debated on the floor of the chamber that the Democrats had serious concerns in relation to Tuesday, because of a party meeting—

talk.start.para: —Contrary to the advice we were given.

—Senator Campbell says—and Senator Lees might listen to this—that this was contrary to the advice that the Democrat Whip had given to Senator Campbell. It is very hard for senators who have not been directly involved in these discussions between Senator Campbell and the Democrat Whip, or the Manager of Government Business and the Manager of Opposition Business and so forth. The trouble is that, when the Manager of Government Business is telling one thing to the Australian Democrats, another thing to the Green senators and a third thing to the opposition, it is very difficult for—
—That is what their whip told our whips.

—Senator Campbell, you say it is what `their whip told our whip'—I don't know that. I can only deal with the information the opposition has. That is why these things are normally done in a cooperative and consultative way. That is why it is so much better to be open and consistent in what you say around the chamber. Many people criticise the opposition for many things but I do not think that anyone can criticise us for not being consistent in what we put to other parties in the chamber. We don't run around picking favourites; we don't run around saying one thing to the government, another to the Democrats and another to Senator Brown, Senator Harradine and Senator Margetts. We are consistent in what we say and we do attempt to ensure that all senators in the chambers—all parties—know the position of the opposition. We are constructive when it comes to trying to ensure that these matters are dealt with in a proper and open way.

speech.para: I am afraid that we have now a situation where the Manager of Government Business operates very differently indeed. Of course, what is happening here is that, earlier in the week, the Democrats were dudded by the Manager of Government Business. I hope that, by now, the Democrats realise they were dudded by the government in that way. I hope they realise that, because they were concerned that the opposition had indicated it was willing to vote for the motion. We may well have agreed to that motion without full knowledge of the facts, but there is a situation here and we all know how it works. Senator Campbell comes along and says, `This is the motion. The Democrats have agreed, the Greens have agreed and Senator Harradine has agreed—do you think the opposition could cooperate here?'

In the spirit of the way these things ought to work, you generally go along with the flow. That is the way it is put to each group in the chamber, as I think now most non-government senators are aware. But I said at the time—last Tuesday, when we were debating this issue—that, as far as the opposition was concerned, we did not think that, given that there would be Democrat party meetings, and given that many senators would be arriving on Tuesday morning because of the public holiday in some states on Monday, it was appropriate that the Senate sit on Tuesday morning next week. I made that very clear when this matter was being debated early in this sitting week. The opposition tends to be consistent with the position it put down at that time. We have made it absolutely clear that sitting the Senate prior to the ordinary time for commencing on a Tuesday sitting day—that is, at question time at 2 o'clock—would be inappropriate in those circumstances. I think that is still the case.

talk.start.para: —It is still the case. We will be sitting at 12.30 p.m.

—If Senator Ian Campbell respects the fact that it is not appropriate for the Senate to commence its sittings on Tuesday before 2 o'clock, then his motion should reflect that; it does not reflect that at the moment. It proposes that there be an extra 1½-hour sitting from 12.30 p.m. to 2 p.m. on Tuesday next week. As I have indicated in relation to the opposition's attitude on this issue, we believe that commencement of the Senate sittings on Tuesday prior to question time in the circumstances of Monday being a public holiday would be inappropriate, and that was made clear.

speech.para: I am not clear even now what the position is in relation to the Democrats and their party meeting on Tuesday prior to question time, and no doubt Senator Lees will be able to inform us of this at a later stage. But I am very clear about the way the government is trying to handle its legislative program—that is, trying to pick off each party or each senator individually, saying one thing to one and another thing to another, and then expecting the Senate to operate in a cooperative and constructive way. It is no way for the Manager of Government Business to run the show.

No doubt he has been on the phone to Mr Howard and Mr Costello—it would be easy enough for him to do so—saying, `Look, we dudded the Democrats earlier in this sitting week, and we got an extra few hours because we got the Labor Party's votes.' Probably as a result of what has happened before us today—and the Democrats might give this some consideration—he will be able to ring Mr Howard and Mr Costello and say, `Oh, I dudded the Labor Party today. We got the Democrats' support for a few extra hours on Tuesday, and I've been able to work this up well in the chamber.'

I think most senators know that this is always a self-defeating way to deal with the Senate's sitting timetable. It never works when you try and play favourites; try and play one party or one senator in the chamber against another. It always harms you. It always disadvantages you in the long term.

The opposition, for its part, in trying to get through this exhaustive legislative program that we have, was going to give serious consideration to not progressing general business on Thursday of the next sitting week. What is the point of us not dealing with the important matters the opposition has to bring before the chamber if the government con tinues to ignore proper process and continues to fail to consult with the opposition and other parties in the chamber as it works through its legislative program and the sitting timetables of the Senate?

It is a very inadequate way for the government to approach such an important task. It has never worked in the past. You would think that Senator Ian Campbell now had sufficient experience in being Manager of Government Business to realise that you just cannot try and pick off senators and pick off political parties in this chamber in this way. You have got to be consistent in what you tell all political parties.

There is really an integrity issue in this. That is why I objected so strongly when the Democrats suggested earlier in the week that the Labor Party had agreed to a government proposal to extend sitting hours without consultation. That is not the way we work. We always try and seek and hear the views of other senators in the chamber. In relation to what occurred on Tuesday of this week, it was only the Greens that had expressed a view to us and unfortunately, because of difficulties at the whips meeting, I think there were some misunderstandings about what the views of the Democrats were. We always respect the fact that political parties have meetings and that the Senate needs to take account of those sorts of issues.

The way to deal with this, which I think is a middle course of action and a reasonable approach in these circumstances, is to commence the sittings of the Senate at 2 o'clock on Tuesday. I do not know what the views of other senators might be—no doubt we will hear them in this debate—but in these circumstances, as far as the Labor Party is concerned, we can mount a case and an argument for the Senate again to sit on Tuesday evening of next week. The government's current proposal is that the question for the adjournment be put at 11 p.m.

Last Tuesday we had a situation where that debate on Tuesday was limited to second reading speeches on the tax package. That is behind us now. The second reading debate has concluded. We do think, however, it might be sensible—given there may not be agreement for the Senate to sit on Tuesday evening—for the Senate to sit at that time but to do so on an understanding of no divisions and no quorums. I would invite senators to give consideration to that approach as a middle course here.

I do not believe the Senate should commence its sitting at 12.30 p.m. on Tuesday. As I have said before, the Senate should commence at the normal commencement time on Tuesday, which is 2 o'clock in these circumstances. If Monday were not a public holiday in some states and if the Senate had been sitting on Monday, we would have a different situation. But the Senate does need to be flexible when it looks at extending its sitting hours. I will formally move amendments to part (a) and part (b) of the motion before the chair. I move:
Paragraph (a), omit "12.30 pm", substitute "2 pm".
Paragraph (b), omit "from 12.30 pm to 2 pm and".

I extend to the Senate the invitation to consider the question of the Tuesday evening sittings, which the opposition will agree to, to be conducted on a no divisions, no quorums basis. I point out that at least this is a slightly better procedure to the one we faced earlier.

talk.start.para: —It is one step in the right direction.
—I accept that, Senator Lees.
—One giant step for Neanderthal man.

—That is probably true too, Senator Ray. We made the point very clearly on Monday of this week as we looked at this issue that, when you laid down the notice of Senate sitting times, it would have been better for the government to have included its proposals for Tuesday of this week in its original notice.
—We have Friday instead of Monday.

—That is true, Senator Lees. I think you agree with this point. At least we have here a notice that does allow the Senate to give consideration to this issue in advance of the Senate's next sitting day, which is a slight improvement.

speech.para: But there is an awful lot of room for improvement with the Manager of Government Business. I hope that the minor party senators are now awake to the fact that they, as well as the opposition, are being manipulated in this inadequate consultation process that the government engages in. You tell one senator one thing or one party one thing, another party another, and you hope in the end that you get the result you want. It is a Pyrrhic victory because, at the end of the day, you waste more time when you do not tell the truth than you do if you are honest, open and transparent with all senators.

I know that Senator Campbell will probably produce another—what does he call it?—roadblock document and say that he has been successful on this occasion in conning the Democrats on Tuesday of this week and he will con the Labor Party on Tuesday of next week. I read his last media release which was under the heading of `Slinky'. Let me quote it so senators know what we are dealing with. This is the Manager of Government Business on 16 April. In the first paragraph it says:

Labor has employed additional arsenal to block the Government's legislative program said Senator Ian Campbell, Manager of Government Business in the Senate, Senator Ian Campbell, at the launch of the fourth edition of Road Block .
That is how it starts, and I can assure senators it gets worse as it goes along.

talk.start.para: —I think you would enjoy it.
—Senator Campbell, did you actually write this yourself?
—I think it was all my own work.
—So you are responsible for a paragraph that reads—let me read it again:

speech.para: Labor has employed additional arsenal to block the Government's legislative program said Senator Ian Campbell, Manager of Government Business in the Senate, Senator Ian Campbell, at the launch of the fourth edition of Road Block .
He is also responsible for this great sentence:
Detailed consideration of the Appropriations Bills were moved to Senate Estimates Committees to supposedly decrease lengthy debate in the Chamber.
I commend this to people. This is just gobbledegook. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —This is, as I said, one step further in the right direction in that at least we have a motion before us that we can debate, unlike last Tuesday. However, I do not accept the government's excuses for asking for extra time. At the time we looked at the tax package, how we would need to debate it and how long it would take to debate it, we actually slotted in these two Fridays to make up for the public holiday. So we cannot have the excuse that we are not sitting on Monday. We are actually getting more government business on Friday in replacement for what we are missing.

speech.para: So the excuse came that we have lost about 4½, five or six hours—in fact, it is probably closer to four—because the Democrats were not ready for the committee stage. We all know the reason for that: because you put on six or seven extra hours last Tuesday to hurry the second reading stage through so we would have problems getting ready for the committee stage, and we did not even see your amendments—128 amendments—until Wednesday. I find this process extraordinary. On any other piece of legislation where people were struggling to get ready what is a very complex set of amendments to some 27-odd bills there would be time given, not time shortened—cooperation, support and time given. But, instead, we have this government working in the other direction.

However, when this was put before us yesterday we were prepared to consider the extra hours that the government wanted. But we said we were not going to have the system that we had this week—in fact, I think the discussions were the week before. So we asked Senator Campbell to make sure that Senator Harradine had seen it, that the Greens knew that the motion had been moved and that Senator Colston and the Labor Party knew. We know that we do not have consensus, but we wanted an assurance that at least people knew what was going on, and we were given that assurance. And, while I understand that there are still people not happy, at least we have a process where there has been some discussion and an attempt to reach a solution.

But can I say to Senator Alston, in particular: we will not be agreeing to any further extra sitting hours for the entire remaining period of this debate without leaders and whips meetings that people attend and work through constructively. We do not want any further individual approaches to anybody. But, instead, we want to actually sit down and work through cooperatively, as we used to do in the past. Then we would not have any need for these debates. We would all know what was going on. We could argue the points as to whether or not we actually needed the time. At this point we certainly do not need it. We got through the second readings very efficiently—in fact, we would argue far too effectively from the government's perspective in terms of forcing us into a corner.

So I put you on notice that the Democrats will not agree to any additional sitting hours beyond what is formally down on paper, unless we have had proper consultations and unless reasonable agreements have been reached. We may not get complete consensus, but at least we would have gone through a democratic process of consultation, giving people an opportunity to discuss it.

I am going to make some further points when we actually get on to the legislation, but I would like to say here that I do find the government's attitude to this legislation extraordinary. In my 10 years as a senator, working with governments that do not like the Senate—you lot were no different when you were in government; you did not particularly like dealing with us—

talk.start.para: —We never showed contempt; we tried to hide it.

—Thank you, Senator Ray. In most cases I think you did an admirable job. But we do have a situation now where our job is, I believe, being deliberately made difficult by government. I have survived, I think, something like four health ministers in my time here. I still have the health portfolio. While from time to time we have to agree to disagree on some particular aspect of amendments—that is fine—I have never before experienced a situation where the govern ment's attitude and the minister's attitude is, `Just keep the pressure on. Don't let them relax for a minute. Push the debates through quickly. Force them into committee when they are not ready. Don't negotiate. Just keep the pressure on.'

speech.para: So I say to government, and I will expand on this once we get to the legislation, here is another example of your minister's attitude to negotiations: `Keep the pressure on. Ask them for more hours before we have even got into the committee stage to know how many hours we want. Don't sit down and talk about the key issues. Don't wait for our amendments. There is no discussion about your amendments, because you won't leave your principles at the door. Just keep the pressure on and keep blaming the Senate.'

But we are not going to stand in your way for next Tuesday. We will agree to the extra sitting hours. As Senator Faulkner has already said, we have a major problem with Tuesday mornings. That has been overcome by government. They have moved it from 9.30 to 12.30, which accommodates our needs.

I do understand, however, Senator Faulkner—and this is the sort of issue that should be raised at leaders and whips meetings—that there are some senators who have to travel considerable distances to get back from what will be a long weekend. So I think we do need to take account of that. I hope that the government will be sympathetic to some additional pairs, if necessary. Indeed, I understand that Senator Cook, who is in Western Australia for the weekend, is going to be leading the debate for the ALP, so there may indeed be some considerations there. This is the sort of issue that should have been raised at leaders and whips meetings before individuals were approached and pressured to agree.

talk.start.para: —Why do you have to respond to pressure?
—We are not. This is the whole point with our amendments. We are not rushing our amendments. You, unfortunately, will not have them today in their final form.
—You said you were approached and pressured to agree.
—Absolutely, and we did not agree at the time we were pressured. My colleagues went through the process—
—You have agreed now.
—Have you any idea of the sorts of pressure that this lot are putting on us? We are absolutely having no part of it. We looked at this issue—

speech.para: Senator Carr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —What about the pressure you guys put on?
—Senator Carr. Senator Lees, please address the chair, not individual senators.
—Thank you, I shall make sure I address my comments to the chair.

speech.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Lots. Perhaps this is—
—Order! Senator Lees, would you mind continuing, but please address the chair.

—Thank you, I shall refrain from being—shall I say—`encouraged' to respond to some side comments. But let us just look again at the issue before us. The government is asking for extra hours before they need it, before we have even got into the committee stage. We have been at all times cooperative, but we will not respond to a minister who is simply hoping, I presume, that we will give in on this issue. But our decision today, after consultation yesterday, on the motion before us is that we will support it, but we will support no further motions without leaders and whips meetings. So until Senator Hill returns—
—So you are making changes, but not just yet.

—We have no choice on this one. We are being pushed to a vote now and this is our decision. Presumably, Senator Alston will pass the message on to Senator Hill, who is due to be back about Wednesday next week. From that point on, we are asking government that the normal processes return. In other words, the government is on notice that this is the last time we will agree to any changes without those meetings.

—As I mentioned earlier in the week, we have had some interesting theatre this week. Labor have just provided some of it in the heckling, I guess, and now they are saying there has not been proper consultation. They are blaming the Democrats for giving in to pressure. That is a very interesting concept considering they have been saying, `Bring it on now. Bring it on now.'

speech.para: I notice that we have just now got Senator Cook's amendments. Remember Mr Beazley said there were not going to be substantive amendments to the bill? Well, we have just got Senator Cook's amendments. That is fine, as I was asking where they were; but now, on Friday, we have got some substantive amendments. They are not as wide reaching as some other parties' amendments in the Senate, but the reality is that there are now some Labor amendments for the committee stage, which they had said there would not be. So we have a changed scenario from a few days ago, which is fine, but it is not the kind of message we were getting earlier in the week.

It is interesting that the government did not actually speak to their own motion this morning. That is because the reason given earlier in the week was that the Senate had lost time. We know—and Senator Lees has mentioned—that that is not the truth. This week we have gained in actual total debating time. If the situation is that we are debating a number of bills to the end of June and, in that sense, there is no time—then, in fact, the Senate has gained time in debating some of the other legislation that the government had on their program. It would not have made sense—and the government realise that they would have been cut down in flames if they had given that as their only reason, which was the only reason they had the other day. The reason still does not hold water.

I would have to disagree with one of the proposals put forward by Senator Faulkner, however, in that if we are going to sit on Tuesday night—and from the numbers it would appear that that is the case—and if it is a complex committee stage of a bill, which it is, it really will not work with no divisions. It makes a complex committee stage more complex to put off divisions. We have had some in recent times which have showed just how complex it is. So if it is an important piece of legislation, we need to be as careful as we can in its consideration. If the parties, including Labor, believe that we should be sitting on Tuesday night, then I believe we should sit in a way that allows us to give proper concentration to what we are doing—instead of having to stop-start and put off divisions, then vote on divisions in a way that can be potentially open to error.

So if we are going to sit on Tuesday night, then I do not think it is a sensible solution to have no divisions. Quorums will happen if they happen—sometimes because someone is not in the chamber. But the reality is that it is not a helpful solution not to have divisions on Tuesday night. It is only useful if you are having second reading debates. If the two major parties have decided that it is important to progress this legislation over others, then I say we sit and we make sure that we can concentrate on what we are doing.

As I say, it is very telling that the government did not argue their own case. I think they realise that the arguments they were giving did not hold water. This is about theatre and about appeasing the arguments about who is ready and who is not ready. In reality, all we are doing is gagging a rather silly argument that has gone on this week which nobody really had their hearts in. The reality is obviously that we will sit on Tuesday. It is the position of the Greens (WA) that if we sit on Tuesday, it should be a proper sitting of the committee stage of a complex series of bills. It will only make it more complex not to have divisions.

talk.start.para: —The unfortunate position we have before us today reflects the government's concept of consultation. They seek the Labor Party's agreement to their proposals and, if they cannot get it, they rely upon what they regard as special standing order 39, that is, if you have a majority on the floor of the chamber you can forget whatever consultations are being proposed. I have made it clear that I think Senator Ian Campbell has an extremely difficult task. He is not assisted by the incom petence of the government in the way they have proceeded to deal with this legislation that they claim is so critical to them. He is not assisted at all by approaches to individual parties within the chamber seeking different positions with each of them.

speech.para: We have indicated very strongly from the moment this matter was first raised with us that we had concerns about the additional sitting hours being proposed for Tuesday. This arose essentially because persons involved in this debate are entitled to expect a reasonable time to return to this place after the weekend. Senator Cook, in particular, who is coming back from Western Australia, is entitled to have that provision made available to him. We are entitled not to expect this lowbrow, grubby approach whereby the government comes into this chamber and says, `We have basically got the equivalent of 39 votes, so it really does not matter what you think.'

We have said in discussions that, if there was agreement around the chamber for additional sitting hours, we would reluctantly accept those additional sitting hours. We do not see the need for it at this time, but we are prepared to accept the thrust of that proposition being put to us. We did say, and this is why I support the amendment of Senator Faulkner, that we thought the commencement time should be 2 p.m. and that the evening session should be on a no quorums, no divisions basis.

Some will say that that is not particularly practical. I say to you that that is not the case. It has occurred on other occasions. What can happen is that senators who are not directly involved in this matter and who do have other activities and other matters to attend to should not necessarily have to be kept here until 12 o'clock on Tuesday night as this proposal suggests. Not all of us need to be here until 12 o'clock. It does not really matter to me and to the whips because we will be required to be here—we will be on duty.

talk.start.para: —But we will call lots of quorums though.

—I have no doubt that other senators will now feel the need to make sure that there is proper consideration of these matters by all senators. I think it is only appropriate, if the government wishes to proceed in this way, that there is thorough scrutiny of the attendance of senators in this place. I hope the Greens and the Democrats, who so easily caved into this government's pressure, as we have heard—
—We'll be here.

—Well, that would be good. We will not have any trouble witnessing your attendance on Tuesday night until the conclusion of the adjournment debate. I have no doubt there will be plenty of opportunity for us to have a good look at that. If nothing else, the Democrats' approach to this matter is touching. Their concern to respond to government pressure is moving.
—A bit like All Bran.

—Yes, very moving indeed. I would be delighted to hear what the nature of that pressure is. I find it extraordinary that mature professional politicians find it necessary to come in here and explain to us how concerned they are that they feel the need to respond to government pressure. What exactly is this pressure that you find so difficult? I am touched, and I am deeply concerned about your welfare on these matters.

speech.para: There is a great deal of touching going on in this matter. There is no doubt that the Manager of Government Business has touched us all up because he went to Mr Howard earlier in the week and said, `Look, what a great little arrangement I have here. I have sorted out the Democrats.' By the end of the week he is saying, `What a great opportunity it has been. I have sorted out the Labor Party.' Well, we will see who sorts out whom in this approach. This low-life approach that is being taken, this grubby, bottom feeding approach that this government are pursuing in terms of the management of this chamber, will rebound upon them. As I say, on Tuesday night I anticipate that there will be a very careful examination. I will take the opportunity to see that there is a thorough examination of the record of attendance of senators on Tuesday night, particularly of government senators seeing they are so keen to press these questions in the face of opposition by the Labor Party.

It is not as if we have been unreasonable in the granting of additional hours of sitting. It is not as though we have been uncooperative. It is not as if we have taken a dog in the manger approach to the management of the business in this chamber. Throughout the last parliament and this parliament we have taken actions which the government, when they were in opposition, failed to take. We approached the management of the legislative program on a reasonable basis, on a cooperative basis, with due consideration to a proper examination of government legislation. I think this could be clearly demonstrated by the record.

Let us look at the additional hours of sitting this chamber has undertaken with the cooperation of the Labor Party. In the winter and budget sittings of the parliament in 1996 there was the equivalent of seven additional weeks of government business time—95 hours and 38 minutes. In the autumn sittings in 1997 there was the equivalent of three additional weeks—43 hours and 52 minutes. In the budget sittings in 1997 there was the equivalent of four additional weeks—58 hours and 15 minutes. In the spring sittings in 1997 there was the equivalent of five additional weeks of government business time—66 hours. In the autumn sittings in 1998 there was the equivalent of two additional weeks. In the budget sittings in 1998 there was the equivalent of six additional weeks of government business time—89 hours and 34 minutes. That is a massive productivity increase.

In the 38th Parliament the opposition agreed to the equivalent of well over an additional year of government business time to consider government legislation—that is 27.1 weeks. That is a trend that has continued in this parliament. Already there has been an agreement in the spring sittings in 1998 of an additional nine hours and 14 minutes, and in the autumn sittings in 1999 there were an additional five hours and 35 minutes—a total of 14 hours and 49 minutes. This additional time was to discuss such things as the government's private health insurance bill. We have given additional time to allow the government to present its case in regard to the GST and to examine that case. Already an additional five hours and 35 minutes have been provided to the government in the second reading stage of this debate.

It is not as if we have been unreasonable. It is not as if we are being uncooperative or inconsiderate. I am sure many people will not understand how this is done, but there is a whole series of devices available to an opposition to allow an opposition to put a view. I think one of the great things about the parliament of this country is that there is plenty of opportunity for the opposition to consider the issues. Equally there is an enormous amount of time for the government to pursue its legislative program and have it examined and voted upon.

We have allowed the government to take opposition time, such as consideration of government documents, general business, consideration of committee reports, government responses to committee reports and matters of public interest, when senators have an opportunity to present matters of concern to them. These are all opportunities we have willingly agreed to give the government on the basis of making sure that the government has ample opportunity to put its case. That does not mean we have to vote for the government's case. It does not mean we have to agree with the propositions that are being put to us, but we do believe there should be plenty of time for the government to consider its position in this parliament.

We have given the lie to the nonsense that is spoken about Senate obstructionism—that is, the old hoary chestnut that governments constantly refer to when they cannot manage their program properly and say, `It's all down to Senate obstructionism. If only the Senate wasn't so obstructionist we of course could solve all the problems confronting this country.' The truth is very much different. What we can see from this record is that in the last parliament an additional total of one extra year of parliamentary business time was given to the government to get their lousy program through. Of course, that demonstrated again how wrong they were from our point of view but, from their point of view, it gave them the opportunity to put the case which they say is going to solve the problems of this country.

What this government then does to us is to suggest, `Look, we don't agree with what you're doing on this matter. We'll go around the chamber, we'll get the numbers elsewhere and you can stick it up your jumper.' The cost of that approach is that you might reckon you gain an hour and a half here or an hour and a half there but you lose a lot of goodwill. I can assure you of this, Senator Campbell: goodwill is a commodity that you need a lot of. You need a hell of a lot of it, and you are not going to be able to keep it. You are certainly expending it at a far greater rate than you are accumulating it by these sorts of actions.

When the question arises in the future, `Will you give up general business?' as we were discussing doing on Thursday, we will have to start asking ourselves, and I am sure that people within the Labor Party such as Senator Faulkner will say, `What is the point if you get this level of cooperation from a government that in fact treats you with such contempt?' That is the problem, Senator Campbell. You think it is a real smart alec trick, real clever, to get an hour and a half of extra business time next Tuesday by doing this behind the curtains arrangement. I can assure you that you are going to lose your hour and a half by a simple process of losing the goodwill when senators then take their opportunities and their rights and exercise them to the fullest.

I am afraid that if you rely upon the Democrats in these matters you do so at your own cost. Sure, the Democrats are great fair-weather friends, but they are not so good when it comes to the hard work that is required of making sure that the legislative program is considered properly. If you think you can pressure them—and they are so precious, I know that—so they will tumble to the odd eye-raising exercise and the odd eyeball that you exert their way, then God help this country, that is all I can say.

I am sorry; I should not say that. I am not a very religious man, but I say this to you, and my wife puts this old Jewish saying to me many times: if you ever want to make God laugh, you tell him your plans. Senator Campbell, I say to you that about now you should start telling people your plans, because they are going to make a lot of people laugh. This is your problem, Senator Campbell. You think you have played the smart one on us today. You are going to live to regret it. That is unfortunately the way it works. That is the way it works in this place. You can get goodwill or you can lose goodwill. Senator Campbell, let me assure you: you have lost it.

talk.start.para: —I am not in favour at all of us sitting next Tuesday night. I do not believe it is warranted. It is not as if this just comes out of thin air. There is a lot of pressure on senators to be looking after their constituents and to be meeting a whole range of obligations to the community. The Senate will be aware that with estimates we are sitting for seven of the 11 weeks between now and the end of the financial year. That leaves precious little time for us to be dealing with a whole range of issues which are very important to our constituencies.

speech.para: Senator Margetts interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Margetts says eight weeks. The question is: why should we be sitting on Tuesday night next? It is an effort by the government to expand the sitting times to not just get the GST legislation through before the budget comes down on 11 May but, consequent upon the budget, to get through as many pieces of its legislation as it can before 1 July, when there is a new make-up in the Senate and when the Senate reflects the vote of the people of Australia from October last year. In essence, the Democrats will have the balance of power as far as government legislation is concerned and not Senator Harradine and Senator Colston.
—And all of us.

—And all of us, as Senator Murray quite rightly says. But as you know, Senator Murray, there is not so much likelihood that, as with the judicious and free-minded Greens, we will see Labor or Democrat senators going in different directions to those directions of their whip when the time comes.
—There will only be one of you, Bob. I don't know how strong a point that is.

—It is a well put point, Senator Faulkner, I can assure you. It is one that requires some reflection. The question is: am I as a Green going to be party to giving the government the numbers to get through a whole range of legislation coming down the line in the next 11 weeks including legislation on superannuation, immigration, assistance to industry and two vital pieces of legislation including legislation which locks millions of hectares of Australia's forests into the woodchip industry for the next 20 years and removes all federal environmental laws over the destruction of that forest? That is an example of what is coming down the line. I am not going to be party to fostering the potential for the government to get such legislation through by sitting next Tuesday night.

speech.para: It is not as if we do not have a heavy sitting schedule in front of us. I have heard no senator come up with evidence that in any other previous sitting year have we had a heavier sitting schedule for this time of the year. Normally, as senators know, it is at the end of the year just before Christmas that things tend to crush up and government pushes for extra sitting time to get through a sitting schedule because it is in the interests of the nation that we make sure we get through legislation for the good running of the nation.

But on this occasion it is different. The government is pressuring the Senate to sit longer so that it can get its point of view through the Senate before the people elected by the Australian voters last October are sitting in here, and I am against fostering the government in that end. I believe that the Constitution ought to be altered so that, as with the House of Representatives, the new Senate sits directly after the election so the vote of the people is immediately reflected, and we would not be in this situation. Unfortunately, it is very difficult to see that coming down the line. We are stuck with this situation where a Senate elected in 1996 is dealing with legislation brought in by a government—

talk.start.para: —You are right there, Senator Ray. A Senate elected in 1993—and part elected in 1996—is dealing with legislation brought in by a government elected in 1998. If we wait until 1 July, at least there will be some sort of reflection of the popular will. But that is not the case at the moment.

speech.para: I agree totally with Senator Margetts that, if we are going to have extended sitting hours on Tuesday, we should treat it fair dinkum, we should treat it seriously. If we are going to have sitting hours on Tuesday on a matter as important as the changing of the tax laws of this country, consequent on the enormous debate there has been, senators should be here. That means that quorums should be called if there are insufficient senators in here listening to the debate and taking part in it and that, if there is a dispute in the Senate as to some component of that tax legislation, it should go to a vote then and there in the wake of the debate, not put off until some future time when the Senate is asked to vote on a matter, having presumably not heard the debate.

It is commonsense and Senator Margetts is absolutely right. If we are going to sit on Tuesday, or at any other time, to debate an issue as important as the GST tax package, the divisions and quorums should be available at that time. I am opposed to this motion by the government. It reflects the government's politics, not what is good for Australia. I am also opposed to the move by the opposition that, if we do sit, there should be an absence of divisions and quorums.

talk.start.para: —One of the first questions asked in this debate was by Senator Margetts: why has not the manager attempted to justify this motion? He simply gave notice of it yesterday and moved it today without one reason. The answer to your question, Senator Margetts, goes back into history. Senator Campbell was trained in politics by someone who is no longer here and who always had the technique of entering the debate very late in the piece so he would never be a target; that is, if you come in and just use your right of reply, no-one else can actually contradict what you say. So the easiest thing for him to do here today was to move the motion and sit down so no-one could analyse his reasons, et cetera. All of those will be given in his right of response so no-one will be able to examine the veracity of what he says by way of speaking afterwards.

speech.para: His major contribution today was during Senator Faulkner's contribution when he managed to articulate the phrases `you idiot' once and `you dope' twice. This is the level of maturity we are dealing with in the Manager of Government Business in the Senate. It is the usual petulant performance by Senator Campbell. What Senator Campbell does not know is that I have managed to get hold of his memo to the Prime Minister he sends every week, and I would like to read it into the record here today. It begins, `Your magnificent eminence, I, your humble servant, Senator Ian Campbell, wish to report that, on Tuesday, I managed to con the Labor Party and annoy the Democrats by getting an extra sitting period. Further to this, I wish to add that, on Friday, I managed to con the Democrats and annoy the Labor Party and are thus going to get some extra hours of sitting. Yours sincerely, Master Ian Campbell (aged 39 years 11 months).'

As Senator Carr said, yes, we have been outmanoeuvred on this occasion. Our amendment not to sit between 12.30 and 2 o'clock on Tuesday will go down, our suggestion for no quorums or no divisions on Tuesday night will go down and we will all be here until 11.40 on Tuesday night. Good win, Senator Campbell! Congratulations, Senator Campbell! You will actually get an extra 32 minutes debate on your legislation if I sit down immediately and you say nothing. What a big victory!

We would have eventually signed up to Tuesday night. All you had to do was be reasonable yesterday and say, `We'll scrap 12.30 till 2,' we would not have had this debate and we would now be 56 or 57 minutes into the tax bills. Are we going to do the tax bills today? You have not mentioned that. Do you intend to proceed with the tax bills? Dead silence. Have you not made up your mind yet? You are not going to inform the chamber whether the red is right or not or whether you are going to seek to put it off again until Tuesday. That information is not before us because you did not have the courage to get up and tell this chamber what the situation is. You lack the internal fortitude to put the position forward here just in case.

talk.start.para: —You were told last night.
—What were we told last night?
—You were told last night.
—Is it going to proceed or not, Senator Campbell? Silence again.
—You were probably out to dinner, as usual. You were told last night.
—I see, I am supposed to have been out to dinner last night. You were not entitled to have dinner last night? No Liberal or coalition member ate last night?
—I ate.

—Senator Murray fessed up. Senator Murray has aligned himself with me. He managed to have dinner last night as well. But we want to assure the public, because I know they are worrying, that we did not have it together, did we, Senator Murray?
—No, we didn't.

—So we cannot even establish whether the tax debate will go ahead today. We cannot establish whether it will start at 12.30 on Tuesday, which in many ways may affect a voting decision in this chamber.

speech.para: What we have reminds me of the old Red Skelton film. I do not know whether many would remember it. It was set in the Civil War. The Red Skelton hero happens to be between the confederate lines and the union lines. To get to where he wants to go, he has to walk right down the middle of the battlefield. He then gets a very bright idea a la Senator Campbell. He cuts half a union uniform off, half a confederate uniform off and puts it on so that he is confederate on one side and union on the other. He then gets an even brighter idea. He gets a union flag and a confederate flag and sews them together, and then proceeds to march right down the middle of the battlefield to the cheers of both sides. That is Senator Campbell this week. But guess what?

talk.start.para: —The wind changed.

—Halfway through, the wind changed. I am telling you, Senator Campbell, the wind is going to change. Your ability to play off the Democrats against Labor and the Labor Party against the Democrats will only work a few times. We are mugs; we will fall in a few times.
—You do fall for it.

—The real thing we fall for, Senator Stott Despoja, is that when we give our word we keep it. Even though we find out afterwards it was given on the basis of false information about your attitude, having given our word we will not break it. But we have learnt our lesson. We will not give our word. We will not give our word every time Senator Campbell comes to us for some courtesy, like he did this week, with no papers, and asks for half an hour for government business. Of course, Senator Campbell, you can have it. Well, not anymore you can't. Why should we? Why should we deal with someone who tries to double deal everyone, as Senator Campbell does in this chamber? I want to remind people of the old Sherlock Holmes short story of the dog that didn't bark. There is a case here of the dog that didn't bark. We are going to sit until 11.40 p.m. on Tuesday.
—You are a very literate man.

—Shallowly illiterate, actually. What happened in all these cases when we used to say, `Will we sit late or not?' A very distinguished gentleman used to come into this chamber—white-haired, handsome, with a great background in the medical profession—and lecture us on the evils of late sittings.
—I remember that.
—I remember it too. Can you assist me with his name, Senator Woodley?
—Is he a minister these days?
—Is he a surgeon?

—Not anymore. He is a minister and he is a former surgeon, yet he is absent from the chamber today. You would think after all those great speeches he gave in the 1980s and the 1990s he would have rushed down to the chamber and opposed Senator Campbell's motion, but he does not because he is now in government and he is a team player. Double standards would in no way bother him whatsoever.

speech.para: Our proposal on no divisions and no quorums is not finding favour around the chamber. I understand what Senator Brown said. It is essential that this be a well-attended debate. Senator Brown, others and I are certainly going to keep the government up to the mark on that throughout the entire tax debate. I doubt we will be in a position to have a division on Tuesday because there is so much debate. That is why I think we put that motion forward. We could not have put that motion forward later in the week, but I think it would have been practical for this occasion.

In summary, I congratulate Senator Campbell. He has had an extra six hours sitting this Tuesday thanks to our cooperation. Now he is going to get an extra five hours sitting on Tuesday next week. I congratulate him again. I will tell you something, Senator Campbell: the bill is in the mail.

talk.start.para: —I was not going to speak on this debate because our leader, Senator Meg Lees, has adequately put the case from our point of view, but Senator Carr has provoked me. I was very taken with his Jewish proverb and his reference to the fact that he is not a religious man, although I have to say that in conversation with Senator Carr he has quite an extensive biblical knowledge.
—I bet you've never seen him turn the other cheek.
—I said that he had an extensive knowledge. I did not say that he put it into practice, Senator Robert Ray. There is a difference.
—That is not a very Christian view!
—But I am waiting because everybody is redeemable. That is one of the things that I believe in absolutely: everyone is redeemable.

speech.para: I want to make reference to Senator Robert Ray. I also want to make reference to the Jewish scriptures, because I thought Senator Carr's reference to that Jewish proverb was very appropriate. There is a Jewish scripture that I think also applies to this debate, and it comes from the psalms. It is the reference which says that in the sight of God a thousand years is as one day and one day is as a thousand years.

My reference to Senator Ray relates to a story he told me. The story goes that there was a Liberal, a Democrat and a Labor person about to be executed. They were all given one wish. The Liberal person to be executed was the first to be granted his wish. He said, `My wish is to have a slap-up dinner with all of the special wines that I can imagine.' He was granted his wish. The Democrat was then asked what his wish was. The Democrat said, `I would like to make a two-hour speech on the environment.' He was granted his wish. Then the Labor person was asked what his wish was. He said, `I want to be killed straightaway so I don't have to hear the Democrat speech.' The point I am making is that if a thousand years is as one day and one day is as a thousand years, then in this debate I am sure that will apply. I thought I would leave that for your consideration and meditation, because in Kim Carr's contribution today I was inspired and provoked to make that response.

talk.start.para: —I would never have arisen had I not been extraordinarily confused by the last speaker and felt that the debate needed to be brought back on track. In my younger days I was a student of philosophy, and that stuff is extraordinarily tortuous. I rank it with econometrics—
—And Democrat party meetings.

—You're getting the point. That is the trouble with the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, he has a quick mind. Sometimes when Senator Woodley expounds those kinds of theories and views, it is quite difficult because you do get a little sidetracked from the issue of the day.

speech.para: In discussing this matter, it occurred to me that all too seldom we as a Senate argue for fewer sitting hours. One of the great burdens that 20th century democracy has given people is the mountain of legislation which just keeps increasing; it gets piled on month after month, year after year. Take the example of the select tax committee bills. This is an astonishing point which is inclined to slip by in the heat and the passion and the morality of the whole debate: a set of bills is being introduced by the government which, it maintains, will produce a much more efficient tax system and improve the lives of all Australians—but those bills do not reduce the size of the tax act. They do not reduce that massive tome which has increased exponentially over the last decade or so. In that regard, I would think it an absolute wonder if the Prime Minister would at some time set an objective for his ministers as to the number of bills or pieces of legislation they should seek to withdraw over time, because we are an overlegislated, overregulated society in many respects, and particularly in the area of tax.

Sometimes, quite frankly, the demand for more legislation is counterproductive. There obviously is good legislation, but an awful lot of it just makes our lives that much more complicated. I think that arises from a difficulty that modern governments in our society have in understanding the difference between the parliament and the government. The government is elected to run the country with the existing laws, to deal with international matters, to meet and greet with foreign ministers and dignitaries, to deal with crises that occur both domestically and on occasions in foreign parts and to represent the country. The police have all the laws they need to do the work of the police force. They do not continually need more laws. What happens is that ministers arrive here and forget that their job is to run the country with the existing laws; they think their job is to produce new legislation and get the parliament to sit endlessly.

Having got that off my chest, I want to return to Labor's proposition. I have some sympathy for the position that Labor has outlined today. Without in any way derogating from the views of my leader, I do not agree that, when having extra sittings, we should do so without divisions and quorums. I just do not think that works, unless it is a second reading debate.

But I certainly have sympathy with the 2 o'clock idea because, being very parochial, I am a Western Australian. Many people listening to this debate would not understand why senators get aggravated and agitated about the issue of sitting hours. Everyone in this place knows that a hard sitting week is 80 hours of work at least, and a reasonably consistent week at home would be a 55- to 60-hour week at least. It is a fact that many citizens think parliament only works when it sits. They forget about the preparations, the meetings, the constituency work and the party room debate. Often when debating amongst ourselves, we forget how much ignorance there is out in the community about what we do and what takes up our time. It is an extremely time consuming job—from party political activity to media activity, to meeting constituents, to meeting lobby groups, to reading legislation and to going to hearings.

talk.start.para: —So are you going to cross the floor?
—I am not talking to people who do understand the issue; I am explaining it for the purpose of those who are listening to the debate.
—You are a bit patronising, you know.
—Therefore, when extra time is loaded on to us, as is happening, it can be agitating.

speech.para: Senator Faulkner interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I can see that I have the full attention of the Leader of the Opposition.
—I am worried, in that you sound a little patronising; that is all.
—I do not mean to be patronising. I just mean to explain to people why this is an issue of concern to us.
—Are you going to cross the floor?

—When we come to the question of time, people would know that senators from Western Australia, the Northern Territory, North Queensland and probably other places lose days which their colleagues from the eastern states are fortunate not to lose. If there is a sitting on a Monday, we fly on a Sunday. If there is a sitting following a public holiday, we fly on the public holiday.

speech.para: The point being made by the Labor Party is that, if you sit at 2 p.m., it allows people, such as Senator Peter Cook, to get up at 5 o'clock in the morning in Western Australia to catch the 6 o'clock flight and be here by 2 o'clock that afternoon. That is my point. I know—because I have calculated it—that, in comparison to my colleagues from the eastern states, I lose 20 days a year because I have to travel a day before. That is what I lose; I lose 20 Sundays a year.

If I have a meeting in Sydney, I cannot fly in and out on the same day—I have to be in the day before. It is a fact of life. This is a massive country. I have to be here early on Tuesday so I will be flying on Monday anyway, so from my point of view this particular change does not affect me. But I have great sympathy for those it does. I am repeating a line I very frequently hear from Labor with regard to the Democrats. You have a great deal of sympathy for us, you feel for us—it is quite touching—and all those sorts of words, and I also sympathise with your position on that basis.

When we fly and how much time we lose is a serious issue, so let me be very serious for a moment. I would bet you that research into the lives of senators and members from far-off places would find that their level of home-life trouble is probably greater than those who live a little nearer, just as a consequence of the stress and strain of that much more travel. Maybe that is not true, but that is my instinct. I think I will leave my contribution there.

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Deputy President, we would like to thank Senator Murray for his refreshing contribution, where he recognised—
—You weren't going to speak, Quirkie, were you?
—At least I am in my seat, Minister, before I open my mouth.
—That's all you can say.

—No, I am going to have a bit more to say, and you might get mentioned in dispatches too. At the end of the day, Senator Murray made the case very well for why we should sit at 2 o'clock on Tuesday. It may well be the case that he has to be here early Tuesday morning, but he is not the only Western Australian in this place. What he said was refreshing because, when Senator Lees made the statement about the pressure she feels, I was inclined to call for the lights to be turned down and for some soft music to be put on.

speech.para: The reality in this particular debate is not quite what it seems. We have had a number of things go on here during this week which I think have been rather interesting. The first one was the other day when, in the words of Senator Ray, we were conned. The Manager of Government Business in the Senate came around and wanted some extra hours to enable us to get into the GST debate, and we agreed with that. We were told, as I understand it, that others were in agreement with this—that it would be a mere formality. But not everything is as it seems around here.

A more cynical person might say that the Democrats were not prepared for the debate on the GST, and a more cynical person might say that they would not be prepared until two minutes past midnight on 30 June—or is it 1 July? However, the Labor Party agreed the other day to sail into the debate. What did we find as the week went on? We found that all sorts of rumours were going around about the sitting times for next week. We were told by a number of people, `These things are being planned.' But has there been any serious discussion around the place? Has there been any attempt to get everyone around the same table to say, `Look, there is obviously a shortfall of time and more time is necessary?' Of course, that is unlikely to happen, and the reason it is unlikely to happen is that inasmuch as the Democrats would like this debate in July, the government, for other reasons, would like this debate much sooner.

The Labor Party has always facilitated extra time. I think it was Senator Carr who told us that in the last three years or so we have spent some 37 extra weeks on smelly government legislation. I say that because these are the people who are bringing these proposals before us that are going to take such time. They are going to take time because they are seriously being questioned out there—and, again, not all is as it seems.

I do not want to take up too much more time here today except to say that if some decent cooperation had taken place with the different sides represented in this Senate, then we would not have had the debacle of this week. I point out that we are yet to start the committee stages of the ANTS legislation, and it could have been started two or more days ago.

talk.start.para: —Why did you vote against it then?

—The parliamentary secretary was the one who came in here and gagged his own bill. That is how organised he is—he gagged his own bill. We wanted to debate it, but he gagged his own bill. Why did he do that? Well, we are yet to find out. Maybe when he gets up shortly he will tell us why he gagged his own legislation—the stuff he has told the Prime Minister that he wants to get through here as soon as possible. Every time you turn the radio on, you cannot help hear Prime Minister Howard and the others around the place saying, `Look, it's got to be done.' And now where do we find the parliamentary secretary? We find him talking to the adviser in the adviser's box and not even listening to the debate. I have to tell you: I hope the adviser can put some sense in there. But I do not want to go on with that.

speech.para: It has been customary here today to have a biblical quote, and I do not want Senator Woodley and others to infer too much from that because I suspect when he talked about `irredeemable persons' he was looking in my direction. The good senator might correct me on this, but I think it is in Ecclesiastes that it says, `There is a time and a season, a purpose and a reason'. What we would like to know from the parliamentary secretary is at least two or three parts of that very important quote.

talk.start.para: —As I mentioned a couple of days ago, my definition of the purpose of government is that it is for the administration of the common good. We are part of the government of Australia. The government of Australia of course is the executive, the judiciary and the legislature. The last three speakers, I think, have done what was required in this debate—they have brought a bit of goodwill into it. Prior to that, on a number of occasions, at least on the face of it, there appeared not to be the type of goodwill that should prevail in this chamber. In other words, I think we should take each other as attempting to do the right thing. It may be misguided—and I have probably been more misguided at more times than others—but we can have vigorous debate, although let us not impugn the intentions of people.

speech.para: In fairness, I think the intentions of the Leader of the Government in the Senate, the Manager of Government Business in the Senate and, indeed, the acting leader of the government in this chamber have been impugned. I do not think we should make that judgment. I think we should examine the matters and see how best we can come up with the answers without imputing improper motives to other honourable senators. The question of cooperation has been raised—it is a difficult question. It is a very difficult time for all of us not only because of the fact that the government and the opposition do not have the type of cosy arrangement that occurs in the House of Representatives but also because this is a chamber which is charged with meticulously reviewing the material that comes before it. And we have got to do it. All of us here in this chamber, who were elected by the people of Australia, have got to do it.

That is why I take issue with a view that Senator Brown was expressing this morning. I do not know precisely what he has against Senator Dee Margetts, his colleague, but I would like Senator Margetts to be here during the debate on the ANTS package, on the GST. She has contributed to the committee work on the matter and, frankly, I listen very carefully to what Senator Margetts says on these particular matters. I think she makes a great deal of sense on a number of matters, and I look forward to her contribution on the GST debate prior to 30 June. It is a nonsense to say that we should suspend all business now after a general election and that the Senate should not do anything until after the new senators come in. The people of Australia, I believe, understand what the Constitution says. The Constitution says that senators are elected for a six-year term. To suggest, as Senator Brown is continuing to suggest, that no matters should be dealt with—

talk.start.para: —I've never said that once.
—We can deal with the matters that Senator Brown likes.
—Yes, with whatever he likes.
—Brian, goodwill—come on.
—Yes, goodwill—vigorous debate with goodwill. With the best of will I am saying that it is a nonsense—
—I am surprised at you.
—I am surprised, frankly, that such a suggestion has been made. It has not been made by any other individual member of this chamber because every one of us, and I hope now Senator Brown—
—No, you haven't convinced me.

—I am trying my best—understands what the Constitution says. The Constitution says that we are elected for a six-year term. Senator Brown is saying, `No, no, Senator Margetts should not enter into this debate on the GST.' Well, she has every right to; she was elected for a six-year term. Those of us who have been elected for a further six-year term, until whenever it is—
—Are feeling very tired.
—It is the weight of the world, too.
—Some of us are looking forward to 30 June.
—Yes. Even some of us who are going to be around for another six years are looking forward to 30 June, I can tell you that.
—Not very much goodwill there.

—No, that is said with perfect goodwill—roll on 30 June, I say. But then we come to the question of the government's responsibility. The government has a responsibility to bring forward its legislation in the manner that it considers is the most appropriate in the public interest. With regard to the matter that we are dealing with—that is, the times—I take the view that the government obviously wants to have this matter fully considered next week; it wants extra time to consider it. That certainly is an annoyance but, nevertheless, I believe the government is entitled to suggest that that occurs.

speech.para: But can I make this very clear: in agreeing to the additional times, that should not be regarded at all as an indication of my support for the measure. It should have been obvious to everyone that the measure requires substantial structural alteration before it will get anywhere near meeting the approval of the parliament as a whole—that is as I read what people are saying around the place. So whilst I am voting for the extension of the debating time on the legislation, that should not at all be taken as an indication of my views on the legislation. So I am supporting the motion by the very hardworking Manager of Government Business in the Senate.

talk.start.para: —I will be brief. I would like to make a few points. I would like to thank Senator Faulkner, Senator Carr, Senator Ray, Senator Quirke and others for the advice they have given me on how to run the program.
—It has taken you an hour and a half to get it.

—Indeed, Senator Carr, it has taken an hour and a half to debate this and it is indicative of the approach of the Labor Party in regard to the program. As Senator Carr said, the opposition has been constructive in providing many hours of additional sitting time for the Senate to deal with the legislative program. On the other hand, those hours have been chewed up by some of the longest debates in the history of this Senate.
—We give proper scrutiny.

—I am sure you do give it proper scrutiny. In the last three years we have had seven of the longest debates in Australian history. Between 1901 and 1996—and I do not claim that these statistics are absolutely the last word on it; I may be out by a bill or two—on second reading debates, for example, there were roughly six bills debated prior to 1996 that extended for longer than ten hours and since 1996 there have been seven bills. In the last three years we have at least equalled or bettered the record for lengthy debates in this chamber.

speech.para: For an opposition that has set out to delay debates and obstruct the government's program, that is some mark of achievement. In three short years they have equalled the record that the parliament was able to put together in the previous 95 years. That is undeniable. You might be able to argue over a bill here or there, but the Labor Party—with the assistance on some occasions of some of the minor parties—in three short years in opposition have been able to tally up more lengthy debates than all of the debates in the Senate in the period from 1901 to 1996, a period of 95 years.

To put that in context, honourable senators who sat in this place for most of that period after 1901 and up to the early 1990s were able to speak on second reading debates with no time limit whatsoever. So Labor as opposition have been acting under an enormous constraint in that their speeches during second reading debates are limited to 20 minutes, so they have to add people to the speakers' list ad nauseam.

I will respond to a couple of other points. The only points of any substance that were made in the last hour and a half were made by Senator Bob Brown in relation to the heavy sitting schedule. I am happy to table the record of parliamentary sitting patterns going back to 1977. This shows that the pattern for this year—when you exclude election years when obviously the Senate does not sit for as many weeks as in a non-election year—is relatively light. I am informed by the clerks and the people in the Table Office that the first half of this year is actually a relatively light sitting pattern.

talk.start.para: —What about committee work?
—Senator Lees is right. Part of the agreement reached in November last year was to give up some of the sitting weeks to allow the committees to sit. To respond directly to Senator Brown's point—
—You are not. He talked about the autumn sittings. You are not directly addressing what he said. He said the autumn sitting. You are not actually addressing what he said.

—I hope that by tabling attachment B of the document called `Parliamentary sitting patterns' showing the number of sitting days in the first half of this year and, indeed, for this year, it will be of assistance.
—No.
—If Senator Brown wants to have a discussion on Senate statistics with me, I am happy to have that, but it is not an overly busy sitting schedule.

speech.para: Could I make one other point. We are seeking to sit at 12.30 p.m. on Tuesday. We normally sit at 12.30 p.m. on a Monday, which allows senators such as myself and Senator Murray to return from Western Australia. Unfortunately, as Senator Murray says, that does ensure that Western Australians have to travel the night before. Western Australians, Queenslanders and Northern Territorians have had to make extra sacrifices on their family lives ever since this parliament was formed, particularly since it was placed in Canberra. The parliament has been sitting here since 1924 and they have always had to travel extra hours and extra days. That is a particular strain, as Senator Murray has quite rightly said, on all of our families.

talk.start.para: —Parliament should have been sitting in Melbourne.

—The point of substance that I am seeking to make—with the great assistance of Senator Carr—is that we would normally sit at 12.30 p.m. on a Monday. I put the proposition in the words of Johnny Farnham from his hit single in 1968 that, indeed, this may not be a Friday kind of Monday. To paraphrase John Farnham—as he is called now—in fact, next Tuesday will be a Tuesday kind of Monday. I suspect that, if you can get to parliament at 12.30 p.m. on a Monday when the Sunday is a holiday of course, then senators should be able to get to parliament at 12.30 p.m. on a Tuesday and pick up the hour and a half that we have now lost during this debate.

speech.para: Senator Robert Ray accused me in an otherwise frivolous speech—if not enjoyable for most senators in this place—of not indicating our intentions about why we needed these extra sitting hours. He may have been misguided or misinformed, or he may not have listened to what was said by the government on only Tuesday this week, which was that if we could not commence the committee stage we would be seeking extra sitting hours. We are true to our advertised position in seeking extra sitting hours with this motion. We have made it clear to the Democrats that we would have to have achieved significant progress on these bills—the tax reform bills—during this sitting week. We lost all of yesterday to that, and we are simply trying to make up that time. That was the position we placed on Tuesday; it is our position today. Again, if we are to lose more time, we would seek to extend the hours.

Senator Margetts did make another very important point in the debate, one that I am very happy to respond to—and I think Sena tor Lees might also have made the point very starkly today—that is, the issue of having these agreements made at leaders and whips meetings. We did have the practice of having leaders and whips meetings that Senator Lees and Senator Vicki Bourne from the Democrats did engage in. Those meetings did prove productive on some occasions. I might suggest to some who were in those meetings that they did tend to become unproductive and were sometimes shouting matches towards the end of the last sittings.

The only problem with approaching senators on an individual basis is that you need very clear lines of communication. There was a breakdown in communications with the Democrats on Tuesday. We had been given one set of information by the whip which was different to an understanding that the leader had—that does happen from time to time—and that has been cleared up. But I reject any allegation that I have said one thing to one senator and one thing to another. I have never done that, I will never do that, and any assertion to the contrary is in conflict with the truth. I commend this motion to the Senate.
