subdebate.2.para: That the Broadcasting Services Amendment (Online Services) Bill 1999 be referred to the Select Committee on Information Technologies for inquiry and report by 11 May 1999.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: Omit "11 May 1999", substitute "25 May 1999".

The intent of the amendment is to have the report date extended from 11 May to 25 May. In speaking to that amendment, I wish to place a few comments on the public record concerning the Broadcasting Services Amendment (Online Services) Bill 1999 . This matter has been under discussion on two occasions before the relevant Senate committee, the newly created Senate Select Committee on Information Technologies.

At the first meeting of the committee almost a fortnight ago, the committee had before it a press release put out by the relevant minister, the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Alston. At that meeting there was nothing else before us for consideration. The meeting determined to refer the substance of that press release for an inquiry. After some discussion, the meeting also agreed that, if the relevant bill was tabled in the Senate during the life of that inquiry, the bill would also be referred for investigation.

The chair of the committee, Senator Ferris, foreshadowed to the meeting—and it was recorded in the minutes—three dates for the possible reference review of the Broadcasting Services Amendment (On-line Services) Bill, those dates being 10, 14 and 17 May. A briefing paper was to be prepared by the Australian Broadcasting Authority, circulated to relevant Senate members, and a committee meeting was set down for public hearing next Tuesday evening. At that first meeting a report date was not considered for the Broadcasting Services Amendment (On-line Services) Bill.

Yesterday afternoon there was a second meeting of the same committee, and all parties were in attendance. There was extensive discussion as to the tabling of the bill and possible dates for hearing because of the important matters contained in the bill. It was not possible at short notice to set out an extensive agenda of dates, although it was agreed at that meeting, as I recall, that next Tuesday evening's public hearing would proceed and that there would be a full day hearing on Monday, 10 May. A report date was agreed of 25 May.

Under those circumstances, it is a bit of a surprise to have this motion before us with a report date of 11 May. In fact, if the agenda and dates of the committee had been adhered to, having its second full day meeting on 10 May, it would be a patent absurdity to have a report date on 11 May—10 and 11 May being in the budget week when everyone else will have other important matters for discussion and resolution.

Members of the committee only received the relevant bill, the second reading speech and the EM on Wednesday afternoon. The government proposals in the bill are interesting. It appears they intend to treat domestic service providers and international service providers differently. They have extensive regulatory arrangements, creation of institutions and various appeal mechanisms for aggrieved individuals to pursue rights granted under the bill. The government approach, as I say, is interesting.

The minister in this debate has been playing a considerable degree of politics for the last two or three weeks. He has been keen to portray the government as the sole protector of Australian families and protector of Australian children. That is something that the opposition takes some offence at. I know that the concerns of Australian families and the concerns of Australian children are uppermost in the considerations of all senators in this place. They should not become the subject of party division or simple political nitpicking.

In the outcome of this bill the opposition wants to achieve sound and permanent regulation. We want effective and proper regulation of offensive, pornographic and harmful material that might be accessed in this country from both domestic sources and offshore sources. But what we do not want is to have a public relations sell-out. We do not want some little fix put in and sold out there to the public as a permanent resolution to difficult issues when, indeed, it is a con orchestrated by the government and by Minister Alston.

We all know that it is not, at this stage, technically feasible or technically possible to regulate the content, no matter how extraordinarily offensive or harmful, of material from offshore. The technology may well be in the process of development and, if it is, we encourage that. We will be very interested in the public hearings in receiving submissions about effective and sound regulation of material from offshore from technologically minded people and from those who provide these services.

But I do say, again, that in this debate concerning accessing of pornography, violent material, offensive material and harmful material from offshore the opposition is not interested in engaging in an ongoing PR game, in one-upmanship between ourselves, the government and other players in this debate. We are interested in finding resolution of these difficult issues by sound regulation, and we are interested in going down that path. It is, indeed, a complex area. Some of the propositions that emerge go to the nature of family in this country, to proper family responsibilities and to the role of educational institutions in educating children and other youngsters as to their obligations and responsibilities.

The technology that is emerging may be useful in terms of the filtering devices and the like that are emerging out of the United States and Australia onto the market. The concern of the government in this issue is the regulation of, as I say, pornographic and other harmful and offensive material. This is also the concern of the opposition. There is going to be, apparently, a role for the industry in this debate. The government has foreshadowed extensive self-regulation measures in its draft bill, and they are also of interest and concern to the government.

So, bringing all that together, there are serious issues to debate. There are serious issues that need to be resolved properly and permanently concerning the publication, distribution and accessing of what we all agree is harmful or potentially harmful material. We are not particularly interested in going into a PR game with the government and indulging in a one- or two-day fix that gets you a headline on page 5 but does not solve the issue now and for the next 10 years.

So, moving the amendment to extend the report date by a fortnight, from 11 May to 25 May, gives the opposition time to get on top of the material, to think through the policy position and to engage in proper questioning of the relevant interests that come to the committees and to their public hearings. We do agree with the government that it is a matter of concern that should be resolved ASAP, but we do not believe in these circumstances that an extension of the report date from 11 May to 25 May is unreasonable or unwarranted.

talk.start.para: —I will not reiterate my views on the unseemly haste and priority which has been given to the matters before this particular committee. They are, as Senator Bishop says, very complex and very difficult. They do affect the home, the schools and the wider community. They affect everybody in the Australian community. Everybody in this place, without exception, is concerned about the impact of deleterious material on the Internet on all areas of the community. I say that without exception, and this debate needs to keep that in mind.

speech.para: The fact is, however, that nothing was done by the government about this matter for the first six months of this year, although there had been extensive committee hearings on this matter before the last elections. It is just in recent weeks that this matter has suddenly been put on the frontburner, so much on the frontburner that, of 27 pieces of legislation that the government wants to deal with between now and the end of this financial year, suddenly this matter of controlling material in cyberspace has shot to No. 3 on the indicative list, asterisk notwithstanding.

Can it be dealt with in a matter of a couple of weeks by committee people representing all parties except the Greens, because we got voted out of it? Can it be dealt with properly and judiciously? Does the wider public have time to respond to legislation which, as Senator Bishop said, was only available to parliamentarians last Wednesday afternoon? Are the people in industry, on those matters of social interest—and they are very complex—which are involved here going to have adequate time not only to draw up their submissions to this committee, but also to be able to respond to the committee in such a way that all committee members are fully informed of the extraordinary ramifications of not only the Internet in our lives, but also the efforts that are inherent here in controlling what goes on the Internet.

We do know that the CSIRO and service providers in Australia have warned that it is difficult, if not impossible, to put in place the sorts of censorship mechanisms that the government apparently wants. Notwithstand ing that—and the talk is that the domestic impediment to material going on the Internet may be one thing, but regulating what comes from overseas is another—I side with, I think, every other member of this place in saying that we must know what the options are and we must be able to look at whether regulation is in order and, if so, how to apply it.

But let us look at other matters which are of enormous importance to the community. Let us look at gambling. Is this committee going to be looking at the impact of the Internet facility for gambling on the Australian community and people in the home? We know that gambling has a massively deleterious effect on those people who are caught up by it, not least low income earners where one of the adults in the household can very easily give away money to the poker machines and other forms of gambling that ought to be providing for families.
I am indebted to last weekend's Sun-Herald. In the Gadfly column, which I follow regularly, under the heading `Internet Backflip' comes this piece:
When a politician launches an inquiry, self-interest is usually the most pressing outcome.

talk.start.para: —Except in your case.
—Thank you, Senator Alston, I will take that on board. To continue:

speech.para: So when the Federal Treasurer, Peter Costello , launched his Productivity Commission Inquiry into Gambling , it was widely interpreted to be the Government's first step towards getting in on a piece of the State's taxation action.
That action is derived from our $10 billion-a-year—and growing—gambling habit.
- that is, Australians spend $10 billion a year in gambling. Back to the article:
But calls made at the inquiry for federal legislation to ban or at least nationally regulate internet gambling have obviously caused a rethink in the Howard government.
Communications Minister Richard Alston told the media last week it would be "technically difficult" to ban internet gambling.
"We are not passing the buck, but gambling is a state responsibility," he said.

So while Canberra pulls out all the stops to ban access to pornography on the internet, gambling online conveniently goes into the too hard basket, even though US authorities have had no compunction or trouble banning online gambling.
And then this:

Of course, the fact that Australia's richest man has said publicly he wants to use his stake in Crown casino to develop a worldwide internet gambling facility, would have nothing to do with it now, would it?
I think the government has been caught out here.

I challenge the government to say that gambling in Australia is a lesser problem than invidious material being available on the Internet. I wonder why the government has given precedence, as a priority, to preventing the enormous ramifications of gambling on every aspect of Australian society, in particular on the home. Why is that not being brought up as an urgent committee matter? Why don't we have legislation No. 3 out of 27, `To regulate the horrendous impact of gambling'? Add to that—and Senator Harradine will know—`and the destruction of lives through the scourge of gambling addiction.' We know about this in Tasmania, where the first casinos in this country were set up. This now very threatening access to international, as well as domestic, gambling facilities—being promoted, apparently, by Kerry Packer and others with, for example, Crown Casino being a centre for a worldwide Internet gambling facility—alarms me enormously.

One does not have to have too much of an imagination to know how that will affect many Australians and, in particular, innocent Australians who depend on breadwinners who are caught up in gambling and losing money. And with that, very often, there are the pathetic cases we all know about involving not only the loss of money but the loss of houses, of businesses, of livelihoods and of marriages, families and children's prospects across this country. If they are doing something about that in the United States—and this article says that they have had no trouble banning online gambling—if they have gone that far in the United States, surely we can be making the first steps to look at it here in Australia. I would have thought Senator Harradine would want this to be a matter of urgency. I would have thought that it has more urgency than even some of the matters that this committee is looking at.

I reiterate that there is a need for this committee. I reiterate that the matters this committee will be looking at concern every person in this chamber as well as every Australian. But what I do not go along with is the crass urgency which is being given to this measure to enable a government which wants legislation like the GST and the sale of Telstra through to be facilitated. And you cannot disconnect the two things. This is manifestly an abuse of good management of parliamentary business. This is manifestly kicking aside more important issues to fulfil a political schedule being set in the Prime Minister's office. I do not go along with that.

The committee should be sitting. But to say now that we ought to direct it to have finished deliberations, written its report and reported here to this chamber within the next month is ridiculous. It is a political outcome, not a good outcome for the people of Australia. If this was being taken seriously, it would have been on the agenda of this Senate months ago and, if it was being taken seriously now that it is on the agenda of the Senate, there would be adequate time for it to be properly deliberated. You cannot tell me that that is going to be the case in the next four weeks.

Sure, we will get a report, but I will tell you, Mr Acting Deputy President, what sort of report we will get. We are going to get one along already set party political lines. It is not going to reflect the wisdom and the expertise and the insight of experts throughout the Australian community because this committee simply is not going to get time to hear that advice—now that we are a year or more away from previous sittings which did take into account some expertise. This area is moving so quickly and there are such enormous innovative efforts being made to control the Internet in other countries that I do not believe all that information can be adequately assembled, put before this committee, absorbed by the committee people and reflected upon—the inevitable questions arising therefrom being settled—with a fully informed and comprehensive report coming back to this Senate by 25 May.

I would have moved that the hearings should at least extend until 8 August, which is when we come back after the winter sittings. That would have given a proper time for due deliberation. That is not available under this proposal by the government. While I will support the opposition amendment simply because it provides for an extra fortnight, it is not a fair go either as far as this committee is concerned and as far as the public interest in the matters of the community is concerned.

talk.start.para: —I rise to make a few comments with respect to the motion before the Senate proposing that the IT select committee report back on the Broadcasting Services Amendment (Online Services) Bill 1999 on 11 May. In speaking to our amendment, which proposes to remove that reporting date to 25 May, it is worth traversing the activities of both the minister and the IT select committee to date. It is an interesting story.

speech.para: What we are seeking to do is have an adequate and a logical process of scrutinising the content of this bill. The ability for the Senate to seek public views, to have the time as a committee to prepare recommendations and to analyse the bill to the degree necessary is why the IT select committee was established in the first place. In recollection of the re-establishment of that committee, we debated in this place for some time the relative merits of that exercise. Identified as one of the key motivations of the re-establishment of the IT select committee was in fact consideration of these bills.

To put this particular debate into context we have to go back a number of years when many industry and community people started getting together to talk about the challenge presented by the new medium of the Internet and access to information. A number of organisations, including industry groups, began talking about what constituted an effective means of maintaining community standards in such a way that it did not create impossible technical expectations to achieve a degree of community standard on the Internet.

It was interesting that as this debate progressed—and I know that Minister Alston's office was involved in negotiating with the industry the development of a code of practice—a lot of goodwill was displayed by all parties involved and, indeed, progress was made over the last year or so. It was with some surprise and, for many, anger when the minister chose to hijack what was quite a constructive project in developing a self-regulatory code of practice for the industry which did reflect and did take into account the community standards issue at the time. At that point the minister issued a press release which articulated the government's intention and left that progress within the community out on a limb.

The next phase, if you like, in this whole course of events saw the committee put together a very shabby motion to reconstitute the IT select committee. In doing so, they forced a debate in this place which identified a whole series of, I suppose, allegations about the motivation of the government, of the minister, in providing a reason for the re-establishment of that committee. It became patently clear that it was something the minister had done off his own bat as part of a motivation to serve other politically expedient ideas that the government had at the time.

What ensued was a subsequent debate about the actual terms of reference because the government's motion originally did not contain terms of reference with respect to the re-establishment of that committee. During that particular debate the point was raised about whether the consideration of the proposed bills by the government would be considered by the committee. An additional term of reference was placed within the charter of the IT select committee. As my colleague Senator Bishop has said, that committee met two weeks ago to decide their program. At that stage all the committee had before it as a reference was a press release issued from the minister's office which articulated a certain proposal.

Yesterday, when the IT select committee met to discuss the timetable for the bills which had been referred to it, a very practical discussion ensued in relation to what was a suitable timetable for due consideration of the bills. Our amendment today reflects, in my view, what was acknowledged as a reasonable timetable that did not attempt to extend the period of consideration of the bills beyond a point of reasonableness, but it acknowledged the need, because of the technical nature and complexity of this bill, to give an opportunity for those who have an interest in the community to come before the Senate committee and express their view.

In doing so, the IT select committee would be not only servicing the specific term of reference that was inserted into it previously but also serving the purpose that the minister has asked it to serve, which is to inquire into the relative merits of this bill. We have heard so much rhetoric in this place about the need to explore what options are available. The proposed date of 25 May allows for a time frame for those options to be explored. It will still be a very tight timetable, and the committee will have to schedule hearings during Senate sitting times, it seems, to actually perform that task, but at least it will give us an opportunity to traverse those issues in some detail worthy of the magnitude and the significance of this particular issue.

Hence, this morning we heard that Minister Alston has in fact disregarded what I considered the acknowledged view that this was a reasonable time frame and he came here this morning persisting with a motion that calls for a reporting date of 11 May. This more than anything else shows that the government, indeed the minister, is controlling this agenda. The IT select committee members have not had the opportunity to traverse, explore and inquire into this bill in the way we see fit and which is necessary for us to do a comprehensive job of bringing forth in the public arena the myriad of issues that we will be confronted with in discussing these bills. We are asking for a reasonable time frame for the consideration of these bills. We do know they are complex. We do know they are controver sial, and I will make a few comments about that shortly.

I turn to some comments made by Senator Harradine which I know were made in absolute good faith. In the context of the previous debate about the terms of reference and the establishment of the committee, he said, `Let us see what merit or otherwise there is in the government's propositions in respect of the Net.' That is all we are asking to do, Senator Harradine. We want the opportunity to explore what merit or otherwise there is in the government's propositions with respect to the Net on this particular issue. We are hopeful that the IT select committee, albeit within still a tight time frame if we report on 25 May, is in fact able to do that.

I now turn to this issue generally. Whilst the role of the IT select committee is confined to the consideration of the bill at this time, there is no doubt that we are at a point of a coming of age of the online community in this country. Debates about censorship of the Net do extend far beyond just the content of this bill, and yet the minister knowingly has provoked a debate that is occurring now in cyberspace. There is a storm out there. I expect that, as parliamentarians, we will receive thousands upon thousands of e-mails with respect to this issue. Why? Because for many people the debate we are currently experiencing traverses many issues beyond what is currently articulated as the intent of the government's proposals, regardless of the relative merit of the content of those proposals. This coming of age for the Internet in this country is something that this parliament needs to acknowledge—that is, there has been a change and there is a change at this time in how we as a parliament need to address our constituency's concerns.

No longer can we as a parliament pretend that there is nothing happening on the Internet. No longer can we pretend that there is not a cultural shift and that somehow we have to deal with that. Indeed, no longer can we pretend that legislation relating to the Internet is something that can be dealt with hurriedly or almost surreptitiously in this way whereby it is being pushed through the parliamentary process with what seems to be undue haste when there is, through our amendment, an opportunity to traverse it comprehensively and at least with some diligence. These issues are a broad challenge for the parliament. It is my hope that support for this amendment will be found so we have an opportunity to, at minimum, traverse the contents of this debate with the level of diligence it deserves.

talk.start.para: —The Democrats will support the amendment that has been put forward by the Australian Labor Party in relation to an extended reporting date for this committee. I do not believe that it is a particularly unreasonable request to extend that reporting date by almost a fortnight. Given the seriousness, the specificity and the comprehensive nature of some of the issues and legislation under discussion, that is not a bad thing.

speech.para: We seek not to—to use a phrase that I think was used perhaps unfortunately—`blow out' the committee reporting date. That is not our intention at all. It is just simply, as most members in the chamber have suggested, to ensure that there is adequate time for debate, time for consultation and, more importantly, adequate time in which to receive information and submissions from those various relevant witnesses—indeed even if it means getting up to speed, to paraphrase some senators. Bear in mind that this is a reconstituted IT committee. It is a new committee and there are some senators who have not served on the committee before and who may want additional time to familiarise themselves with some of the work that has been done.

We are asking for a couple of months. I think that is an entirely reasonable request. My party and I are genuinely sorry if members in this place or the government feel that this is an unwarranted extension of time. As Senator Lundy referred to, we had a reasonably cooperative committee meeting yesterday in which everybody sought to find out what time they had available to meet as a committee. Given some of the pressures of debates and committees and legislation before the Senate, I actually thought we did a pretty good job in trying to mull around to find some dates that were acceptable to everybody. That leads to two broader issues—that is, the amount of legislation before us and the assumed urgency relating to some of these bills.

Clearly, the key area of debate before us at the moment is the taxation legislation. The government has impressed upon all parties in this place the need to deal with that as soon as possible and in great detail. Certainly, we accept that and we do not doubt the importance of the bills before us that relate to technology, particularly the Internet and broadcasting. But I do doubt the degree of urgency with which the government has argued that they should be dealt with. They are important. They need to be dealt with in the next couple of months, but I am a bit surprised today to hear of time lines that suggest not only a reporting date in the next couple of weeks but also that these bills be debated and dealt with in budget week. Senator Brown has referred to the timetable that has been put before us. There is this sense of urgency relating to all bills.

There is also a second issue here—that is, the role of this select committee, bearing in mind it is a select committee. This was touched on by some senators yesterday. The fact in this case is that a select committee is effectively functioning not only as a references committee with the potential for a number of wide-ranging references on a broad range of topics but also as a legislative committee as a result of the reference of these particularly relevant bills to the committee.

We are going to have to evaluate this further—and I think this is appropriate, given the rush and the procedural debate that accompanied the passage of the terms of reference for the committee. It is appropriate for us to continue to evaluate and monitor the ongoing role of the select committee.

A select committee, of course, raises other problems for members of parties, specifically minor parties or Independents—and Senator Harradine and I are two of the members on this committee—that is, it is not possible to have substitute members. I know that the suggestion has been put forward by some, including our chair, Senator Ferris, and not unreasonably so, that we look at subcommittees. In this case for this particular set of bills, which I would suggest would probably be the most important bills before this select committee this year, or certainly in this parliament's time, I actually think we should ensure not that subcommittees are present for those debates, discussions and committee meetings but that we have a full complement, in as much as we can a full complement, of senators. So I do ask the government and also the chair to take that on notice too: that we continue to ensure that we involve as many members of the committee as possible.

The Democrats believe in the importance of this bill, but not necessarily the time line that has been outlined. I will not talk more about the time line as I outlined in the committee meeting yesterday some of the concerns that I and my party had, and certainly I think the extended date put forward by the ALP solves some of those concerns.

In relation to some of the policy matters, in some ways I support comments that Senator Harradine has made a number of times, that is, let us get it out of the way. I think that by 25 May we will be able to have this report and, following that, the legislation out of the way. I do not want to see this information technology committee in the Senate hijacked or bogged down in policy matters that yes, are important but are one part of a range of policy areas that we should be investigating as part of our work. I have put on record many times before, not only as a member of this committee and the committee in the last parliament but also as a member of the precursor to that committee—the community standards committee, as it was then known—that the Democrats have long believed in the formation of a specific information technology committee.

We have long put forward ideas and recommendations for evaluation and report, and they are not specifically to do with illegal and unacceptable material on-line, although we acknowledge the importance of that. It has been canvassed in a fairly goodwill kind of way in the chamber today—everyone acknowledging that everyone has a concern about illegal or offensive material on-line, especially in relation to the impact on minors, on children, in our community.

talk.start.para: —That's what we're trying to deal with.

—And I do accept that. We are trying to deal with that. That leads on to comments that have been made in reports previously and in the chamber today—that is, it is an incredibly complex issue not simply because of the philosophical or our intellectual responses to this debate but also because of the technical difficulties associated in this debate. In the last committee reference which dealt with this kind of material on-line—and I was a member of that committee that reported—I did a comprehensive report on behalf of the Democrats that looked at some of these feasible technical difficulties that come with filtering, blocking, stopping, controlling or regulating information on-line. So there are those two aspects that make this debate worthy of an extra couple of weeks of consideration.

speech.para: A lot of people could happily wax lyrical, as I am sure many of us will in this place, about the positive features of the Net, the democratic power of the Net, if you like, as a channel of communication, as a medium for information. There are people who talk about the potential dark forces of the Net, and I noted yesterday the comments attributed to the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Kim Beazley, in relation to the unfortunate and tragic occurrence in Colorado where he said that the uncontrolled growth of information on the Internet had probably helped contribute to the massacre.

There is this whole minefield of issues and assumptions about the Net that legislators as well as members of the community generally have about the role of the Net, and that leads on to the issue of regulation. Still I note that the government sought to respond to the reports that have already been tabled in relation to on-line technologies not only by the precursor to this committee but also by the ones before that in a single response. Hence, the legislation that is before us.

I note that on 19 March the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Alston, announced the government's policy for regulating the Internet but, to date, the government, as far as I am aware, has not actually responded specifically—I acknowledge it has responded in the form of legislation—to those outstanding recommendations that are contained in previous reports. Reports in 1997 were for part 3, the on-line regulation report, and those in 1995, I think, were for part 2. So we have not actually seen a detailed response, and I am happy to be corrected by the minister if that is not the case.

I do acknowledge that the single response of 19 March is here today in the form of legislation, but I actually think that most members of this place would benefit from an analysis of those recommendations, the government's response or otherwise to those recommendations and the government's rationale for what changes are put forward. I am very curious too, given that these previous committees have dealt in detail with the issue of self-regulation. I do not really believe that that has been dealt with most properly by the government in relation to any kinds of responses to those recommendations or, indeed, in the legislation. But they are the things that we will be evaluating.

In terms of the broader issues that have been canvassed by Senator Brown, Senator Lundy and Senator Bishop, the Democrats are more than happy to deal with other policy matters in the information economy, information society or information technology area. You take your pick.

Again, I draw the Senate's attention to the final report by the Democrats to the last committee, the report on the need for the committee in the 39th Parliament, signed off on by our very capable chair, Senator Jeannie Ferris. Her recommendation was one that I did endorse: that the committee continue. Certainly the Democrats were keen to see that happen, but we were rather bemused and a bit disappointed by the procedural nature of and the lack of information about the terms of reference that accompanied the debate that reconstituted that committee when we were here last.

I draw the Senate's attention to the report I submitted to the IT committee's final inquiry. The report proposed that a whole range of other areas be explored. Whether to do with self-regulation, encryption, e-commerce, vilification or information property laws, there is a whole range of other areas that I do not think this committee has even begun to grasp. So, yes, I am with Senator Harradine, and perhaps Minister Alston even, when it comes to getting some of these issues out of the way. But that is no reason to rush them in a way that will result in anything but a proper analysis and comprehensive debate of the issues. We have to ensure that we do have such a debate, as opposed to rushing this legislation through for the sake of rushing it through.

I look forward now to perhaps hearing from the government as to its rationale for the urgency in this debate—not as to the importance of this legislation, nobody doubts that—why we should be anticipating debating these bills in budget week and why we need a reporting date of 11 May. Let's face it, it is pretty unusual for a government itself to refer legislation directly to a committee; certainly when we tend on occasion to do it, we hear no end of complaint.

But why should the reporting date be 11 May when the cross-party committee members yesterday, in good faith, identified the best date for a second committee hearing as being 10 May? Even if people are not convinced with the pleas or the concerns of the members of that committee, and members of the Senate generally, then at least think of the secretariat whose responsibility it is to draft that report and have it ready for tabling by the following day. It is not possible.

I am sure that responses will be forthcoming, either in the Senate today or behind the scenes, such as, `Why can't we do it earlier?' or, `Don't we have time?' or, `What about that first nonsitting week?' If anyone was a fly on the wall yesterday, they would have seen that committee members did have other functions and they did have other obligations, be it in their electorates or, indeed, in Canberra—

talk.start.para: —At an estimates committee.

—Or at an estimates committee, as Senator Lundy has just reminded me. Before anyone responds that 3 May is not an estimates committee day, I note that many of the members yesterday identified that day as being one on which they had other commitments; certainly I did. If it had been the will of the committee to proceed on that day, I would have accepted that, albeit reluctantly. But that is no way for a committee such as this to function. It is no way for a select committee to function, given that we cannot have substitute members. We should identify dates and stick with them. I think it was quite extraordinary in the first place for such a tight reporting date to be put forward.

speech.para: As I have said, I am sorry that Senator Harradine was not available; we certainly would have taken his concerns into account. By no means do we intend to suggest that this bill is any less urgent or that his rationale for dealing with it quickly is any less valid. But these are important matters. They deserve comprehensive and wide ranging debate, and that is what we intend to give them. It is certainly not an unreasonable request to extend that reporting date by a couple of weeks. For that reason, the Democrats will be supporting the ALP amendment.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —There are five more sitting weeks to go, the government has publicly and repeatedly identified the priority legislation that it would like to see through the parliament in the current session and this bill is one of those pieces of legislation. The issue that needs to be addressed today is one that, by and large, has been skated over by everyone who has contributed to the debate; that is, of course, the timing of the hearings that need to be conducted by the Senate committee.

speech.para: I am pleased to hear that there does seem to be general in principle support for this legislation and, to the extent that that means the Labor Party is now very supportive of our provision in relation to this legislation, I am pleased to acknowledge that. But this is not a timeless debate. In many respects the debate is still at a fairly immature stage.

I notice that people like Senator Lundy have been sending out emails which offer no constructive suggestions, no alternative approaches, but simply seek to ferment trouble and whip up a storm—a `cyberstorm', as she refers to it. These emails even tell some members of the Internet community that the anticipated report date is 25 May. There has been no basis at all for putting that out. It is simply misleading and dishonest propaganda. However, it highlights the fact that Senator Lundy is not particularly concerned with doing anything other than delaying as much as possible the reporting date.

The issue confronting the Senate at this point in time is: what is a reasonable time in which to enable the select committee to have hearings on the legislation? I understood that this legislation was made available Wednesday morning; I heard Senator Bishop say that it was Wednesday afternoon. But in any event, as you know, it has been out there. The industry itself had a two-day session earlier this week. There has been a lot of consideration given to this legislation since the committee started considering that press release and the issue itself. Quite clearly, a lot of people have been giving a lot of thought to the matter.

As I understand it, the committee hearing yesterday actually preceded a resolution of the Senate. That is not the normal way in which these things occur. It is normally desirable to look at the Senate's timetable, and committees are then subordinate to that timetable. In any event, the committee took the opportunity to see what it thought would be required in order to give a fair hearing to submissions that might come in. It took the view that two hours on next Tuesday evening would be sufficient for a briefing from the ABA and to then hear from the Internet Industry Association, which I think it would be fair to describe as the principal peak body in this area.

The committee also took the view that there should be another opportunity for hearings, but for some reason it chose 10 May. Despite that date being right up against the 11th, the fact is that the committee still acknowledged the 11th as the report date implicitly because there is a clear opportunity there. But it seems to me that that is a tight and unnecessary timetable. Although no-one has mentioned it to date, the Senate will not be sitting next Wednesday; we have heard that from the Democrats this morning. Therefore, there is every opportunity for the committee to hold a further hearing on the Wednesday evening. Indeed, it can sit as late as it likes on the Tuesday night to take submissions and it can sit as late as it likes on the Wednesday night. It could sit Thursday as well, or it could sit the following Monday evening preceding the estimates committee hearings on the Tuesday. In other words, there will be ample opportunity for anyone who is interested in this matter to put their submissions.

It is important to understand that we are not trying to ram through some sort of technical or technological response which we think we have identified and which somehow the rest of the industry has to accept. That is not the government's approach. We have said time and again that we accept that ISPs, for example, should not incur strict liability. They should have only a degree of responsibility if the content providers are beyond the jurisdiction and if there are matters that they can deal with themselves. But it has to be technically feasible to do that, and you have to take account of the commercial considerations involved. What we have in mind is codes of practice developed by the industry which we would hope would be sufficient to encompass these matters so that the government would not be doing anything other than requiring anyone who was dilatory to adhere to those codes of practice and for those codes of practice to be organic, to evolve in such a way that they would accommodate new technology developments.

The reality is, from a number of people who have spoken to me, that hardly a week goes by without someone coming up with a new technological solution. We are not just talking here about new software filtering technologies that parents might be able to use or that they could subscribe to ISPs for clean universes. We are talking here about filtering and blocking technologies or guessing engines or other mechanisms that will enable you to identify sites and to exclude them from the universe. We do not want to get out there and prescribe the technology. What we want to do is have codes of practice that require the industry to take account of the latest technological developments and to use those in support of a principle that I think we all accept.

If that is the case, there is a significant degree of urgency, given that the Senate has only five more weeks before it. If we were to have a report date of 25 May, then you are halfway through the third-last week. You would then have two further weeks. In order to get to 1 July, you would have a truncated week in the second of those last two weeks. Time is of the essence. Clearly we do not want to not provide opportunities for industry to make submissions, but it is not as if industry or members of the community have not been very much on notice over recent months. This matter has had a lot of publicity. A lot of people out there have had meetings on it, discussed it endlessly and taken account of what has occurred in other jurisdictions.

We know, for example, that the American Congress has time and again endeavoured to grapple with this issue—in my view, perhaps heavy-handedly in trying to impose strict liability—and they have run up against the first amendment. We do not have that problem here, but it simply demonstrates that all responsible legislatures are trying to come to terms with a difficult problem. We think we have an approach that could set a precedent for other jurisdictions. In other words, it is sufficiently flexible, by virtue of promoting industry codes of practice, to be able to adapt as new technologies come along.

Given that everyone is committed to the principle, and given that time is fast running out in terms of the priorities for this session, it is very important that we stick to the report date that is contained in the original motion, which is 11 May. There are plenty of days on which further hearings can be held if there is a modicum of goodwill. I simply do not accept what Senator Stott Despoja says—that is, there are other priorities that she may have that are superior to those of the Senate. The fact is that constituent appointments do not take priority over Senate committee hearings. The mere fact that it might be somewhat inconvenient to come to Canberra on 3 May, for example, is no good reason at all to say that you are not available for a committee hearing.

Certainly, when we are all here next week, there can be no excuse at all about constituency demands or any other electorate responsibilities. The Senate is sitting next week. There are ample opportunities to take evidence from any interested parties. Then you have a full non-sitting week with some estimates days thrown. If you put your Senate responsibilities first, you would surely be able to allow additional time. On that basis, we will be opposing the amendment, and we urge the Senate to support the printed report date.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I have a question for the minister. I understand that the way this is going, debates would occur in budget week. I simply want to know that, if the debate on the tax package of bills is not completed by budget week, will the bills be leapfrogged? And will the debate on this legislation and this matter take precedence?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —by leave—The government's timetable will have to be determined as we go. We will be wanting to ensure that we can expedite all of the legislation that we regard as priorities. I am not saying that we will be debating the legislation in that week; we simply want the capacity to do that. That will then involve judgments based on progress being made with the tax package. I fervently hope that debate will have been concluded by the end of next week. If that proves not to be the case, then we will have to make a decision accordingly. I am simply urging the Senate to support 11 May as a date that gives us the ability to bring the matter on if the opportunity is there.

—I wanted to speak briefly on this matter and indicate to the chamber, if the chamber is not already aware of the fact, that this whole issue has had a very long gesta tion. It goes back to statements by representative ministers of the previous government, who were very strong and undertook to do something to meet the concerns of parents about material that is easily able to be accessed. Those were the statements of the previous government. I assume that those policies and those views have not changed.

speech.para: Senator Ferris's committee and the previous committee have been considering these matters for some considerable time—actually for years. The fact of the matter is that the parents of Australia are sick of talk; they want action. This is why there is some urgency about the matter the government has been discussing with the ABA. Mind you, I agree with Senator Bishop that we have to have a very good look at this material to see whether it is going to work properly. The ABA, to my mind, is a very passive regulator at the best of times. If it is going to be responsible for this, let us see how it responds to questions that we have asked of it.

There is a need for further time to be given to the committee, and I agree with that. Quite seriously, I do apologise for not being there yesterday—there was something called the GST that was around the place at that particular time—and I agree, as has been indicated, that there is a need for possibly up to two long evening sessions and a day or two. As has been explained, they could take place next week, the following Monday and/or the Monday after that. I agree that we should not just allow it to be a formality. It should not be a formality if all of that time is spent on it—and that is entirely possible.

I am not happy about some provisions in the legislation, and I will be very interested to hear what the department has to say about those particular provisions. Nevertheless, I think the government is to be congratulated for at least responding to the appeals of the committee over a period of time and for doing so in a practical manner by developing legislation. It is now up to our committee to consider that legislation and to see whether it meets the objectives which I think we probably all adhere to. I would like to say this: clearly if you leave it entirely to the industry itself, the industry is not going to come up with the answers.

I will very briefly refer to the matter that was dealt with—or at least adverted to—by Senator Brown. He read out a news item about gambling on the Internet. For Senator Brown's and honourable senators' information, I met a couple of weeks ago with Mr Tim Costello in Melbourne and with Mr Nick Xenophon. I agree that Internet gambling is going to be a very major concern. With the advances in technology, you will have a situation where the feeling and the atmosphere of the gambling casinos in Melbourne will be in the homes of Australian citizens. It will be virtual reality. I am very concerned about that. I believe that our committee should consider those matters, but that it should not be done in a manner that is going to torpedo the recommendations that have been made and actions that have been taken by our committee over the years, and the views that have been expressed by successive governments and by this government to do something about it and to respond to the concerns of parents.

The matter of Internet gambling is a primary responsibility. The states should take action on that particular matter but so should the federal government. As a member of the committee, I will be seeking to have the matter considered. I thank the Senate, and I look forward to the debate and to a vigorous questioning and examination of the details of the legislation. It is a fact of life that if we do not deal with it now—if we do not set this deadline—we are not going to have this matter debated for months and probably not until next year. I believe the parents of Australia deserve better than that. The people of Australia have said they want action.

That the amendment (Senator Mark Bishop's ) be agreed to.
