talk.start.para: —I have a couple of questions to put to the minister. Minister, yesterday, you made available to the chamber 128 amendments to the GST legislation which, by use of the guillotine, had been put through the House of Representatives before Christmas. That means that the legislation which the government rushed through the House was clearly not properly considered. On further thought, the government has come up with a further 128 amendments.

speech.para: I read in today's press that senior members of the government are considering further amendments in addition to the 128 that have been tabled in this chamber. Therefore, I ask: will there be further amendments? If so, how many? To which bill or bills, or, if you prefer, which topic areas, will they relate?

talk.start.para: —Thank you for the opening question, Senator Cook. I tabled amendments to the bill in the parliament this week—and I think the Labor Party has also now tabled amendments and, hopefully, the Democrats and other senators will shortly also be seeking to move amendments. Those are the only amendments of which I am aware. I do not have any information on other proposed amendments. I do not rule that out and I do not rule that in. I will just say that the amendments of which I am aware are those which I have tabled.

speech.para: There are just over 30 substantive issues in those amendments. Those amendments arose from wide-ranging discussions that the government has had with industry and with people who have expertise in particular areas. We think that those amendments help to address a range of concerns which were put to the government.

talk.start.para: —You do not rule out or rule in the prospect of further amendments, but I have read reports in the press, as no doubt you have, that senior members of the government are considering additional amendments. I have to say that—and I confess it frankly here in public—I have heard rumours that there are additional amendments. I note that, yesterday, Senator Harradine made a speech in which he raised a series of questions. There is speculation that that might bring forth some additional amendments from the government.

speech.para: What worries me, Minister, is that we are kicking off Mr Howard's great tax adventure in the Senate, considering the 27 bills—starting with the first one—clause by clause, and you are not able to rule out or rule in whether or not the government will be introducing further amendments. It is on the record, as it arose during the Senate select committee inquiry into the GST legislation, that a number of organisations gave evidence that they were making representations to the government about further amendments to the legislation.

You have come up with 128 amendments and, as you have described them, some are technical, some are matters of substance and some, as matters of substance, are matters of considerable concern—and loosening of the compliance provisions is one of them, but we will come to that in due course. I understand that you have said that the amendments that you have now tabled are amendments that the government has arrived at after consultation with organisations. Which organisations' evidence have you taken note of and is, therefore, reflected in the sheaf of amendments you have tabled this week, and which organisations, which have indicated public amendments to this legislation, are you either in continuing discussion with or have declined to accept changes from?

talk.start.para: —I will seek to find out whether I can provide you with that detail on the organisations. As far as any future changes are concerned, the remarks I made in my opening answer to your question remain. These bills reflect the tax reform package which was announced last August which was extensively debated during the election. I think you and I shared the same platform on at least one occasion during that debate—and others will judge, Senator Cook, who won that particular exchange. However, I note that the government won the election, with the central issue being tax reform. Following that, bills were brought into the House of Representatives and, following the passage of the bills through the House, we then had a very extensive Senate procedure.

speech.para: As Senator Ian Campbell has pointed out on a number of occasions, this is probably the most extensive inquiry that the Senate has conducted into any package that any government has brought forward. We have received a range of submissions from people. As we have held discussions and listened to the evidence, we have noted some areas in which the government wishes to finetune the legislation, and that has occurred. As to providing names, I will see what particular information I can provide to you.

talk.start.para: —Just on the question of not ruling out further amendments, can you be more categorical about that? Will there or won't there be further amendments?

—As I said in answer to your first question, I have got no particular knowledge of any amendments the government is proposing. I do not rule it in and I do not rule it out. It is a matter which I do not have any particular knowledge on, so I am not in a position to provide you with that type of information. There will be a very extensive debate in this chamber and undoubtedly views will be put forward by people, and the government will always listen to views which are put forward. So I think the answer I gave is a responsible answer and reflects reality.

—What is of particular concern to me, if I can pursue this point one step further, is that the bill before us now is the first of a series of bills, but this is the bill which imposes a GST. Some of the subsequent bills provide compensation. If you cannot rule out amendments, are you asking the chamber to consider the imposition of a tax without knowing whether or not you will change your position on what compensation there might be, particularly to low and middle income earners, whose position is made worse by this tax? Are you expecting us to deal clause by clause with the first bill imposing a tax without knowing whether you are going to amend the compensation provisions that come later?

—This is not the imposition bill that we are discussing. But, in relation to other amendments, it is entirely up to the Senate whether it passes any amendments that the government is proposing. If you are worried about any future amendments, equally it is entirely up to the Senate whether it passes those or not. That is a matter for the Senate. We have acted in a way which I suspect has always occurred in relation to major bills. I can hark back to tax bills which the Labor Party has brought in where we have sometimes had amendments brought forward early and then there have been further amendments. I do not think there is anything new in the procedure which has been adopted. It is entirely up to the Senate whether the Senate accepts amendments which are brought forward.

speech.para: It is quite possible that the Labor Party may be bringing forward further amendments. I understood initially that the Labor Party were not going to be bringing forward amendments to the bill, Senator, but I notice that you yourself have brought forward amendments today. We were surprised, because there was a statement made in the press—this is the danger, as you would always note, of reading the press—that the Labor Party were not going to move amendments. I do not know whether the Labor Party are ruling out bringing forward any further amendments. I suspect that you are not and that you will see how the debate flows. As I said, the government has been up-front with the amendments that we think are appropriate, given our present state of knowledge. We will listen carefully to the debate.

talk.start.para: —My reason for being concerned is that the government, by use of its superior numbers in the House of Representatives, in the debate in the chamber on this legislation applied the guillotine as a matter of urgency to carry that legislation in that chamber prior to Christmas. Obviously you have thought that the scrutiny of that chamber in a full-blown way was not necessary but upon further consideration you have now, of your own motion, moved to amend the bills that were so urgent then. My concern, at the beginning of this debate in this review chamber, is to establish the full extent to which the government proposes to alter these bills here and refer them back to the other house for further endorsement.

speech.para: On the basis that you cannot rule out the prospect that there will be further government amendments, can I say, Minister, that you would be aware of the submission made to the inquiry of the Senate Select Committee on A New Tax System by the Taxation Institute of Australia. You would be aware that the Taxation Institute of Australia is a non-party political body. You would be aware that the Taxation Institute of Australia does not occupy a high profile in public debate in taking a partisan stand on matters before the community on issues of tax, rather that the Taxation Institute of Australia, as it describes itself, is a collection of tax experts, some 10,000 members in all, who are tax agents, who are lawyers, who are accountants, who are members of the judiciary, who are members of the Commonwealth, state and territory governments, and whose principal interest and concern is proper and effective tax law.

You would be aware, I am sure, that in their submission to the Senate select committee this body, which is a credible and respected body in the community, said that they had concerns with the legislation as it stood. On those concerns they made a number of points. They said:
the currently proposed GST regime is not simple, either to implement or to administer. The TIA—
that is, the Taxation Institute of Australia—
notes that New Zealand's GST regime is encapsulated in only 86 sections, compared with in excess of 420 sections in A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax) Bill 1998 .
This could well be indicative of complexity, excess wordage or both. That is the first point that they have made. The second point they have made is as follows:
a comprehensive assessment of the impact of the GST is not really possible in the context of overall tax reform until all the Government's tax reform proposals have been tabled in Parliament;

I interpose at this point to say that what I want to be sure of is that all of the government's proposals, including the amendments, are available to us in this parliament. I go on to cite the concerns of the Taxation Institute of Australia. In the next dot point on the first page of their submission to the inquiry, which is, for your reference, submission No. 899, they say:

the efficiency of the enterprises affected by the GST will be adversely impacted by the escalation in professional costs to meet the implementation and administration requirements of the GST, in particular the cost of valuing assets affected by the GST (. . . by 1 July 2000);
They go on in their next dot point:
the `in principle effect' test in the GST general anti-avoidance provision is far too broad and is inconsistent with the general anti-avoidance provisions in other taxation legislation;
They conclude with their last dot point:
sufficient time must be allowed for the implementation of the GST.

Elsewhere in their submission they call for an independent body to review the legislation to get the devils out of the detail. As you would be aware, Minister, in addition to making those headline remarks, in appendix A to their submission to the Senate select committee inquiry they attached eight pages of suggested amendments to the legislation. Again, I make the point that this is not a party-political organisation, this is not an organisation trying to take a position in the tax debate: this is an organisation that simply wants to see good tax law in Australia and which says on evidence to us that, once it is clear what the direction of the parliament might be, their concern is to see that that direction is implemented efficiently and without flaw.

In the eight pages of appendix A to their submission—I do not propose to read them, of course—they make extensive suggestions to amend the legislation. In my review of the amendments put forward by the government, I cannot see how the Taxation Institute amendments have been picked up or reflected. My question to you at this point is: have any of the changes recommended by the Taxation Institute of Australia been reflected in your amendments or, on further reflection, do you intend to take the advice of a non-partisan political body, expert in these matters, composed of the professionals who administer tax law at the coalface in Australia, and incorporate some of these changes, or do you intend not to?

talk.start.para: —Senator, as I pointed out to you, there has been very extensive exposure of these bills. There has been very extensive consultation. A Senate committee has examined these bills and, in the light of the consultations which the government has had, the government has moved a range of amendments. As far as the Taxation Institute of Australia is concerned, if I recall correctly—I am sure you will correct me if I am wrong—they are very supportive of taxation reform and are supportive of a goods and services tax. They may well have concerns, and you have drawn the attention of the Senate to some of the concerns that they have raised. In the end the government must make decisions. The government must decide what it wishes to do. As I have said, we have looked at some 30 substantive issues and have proposed a range of amendments which have been circulated.

speech.para: Concerning your question whether any of the particular proposals by the Taxation Institute have been picked up in the government's amendments, the advice that I have is that a number of their concerns were addressed in the amendments which we brought forward, including the one that you raised—the general anti-avoidance provision. The government announced earlier this week that we would amend the provision to make its scope and operation clearer to ensure that it does not apply to anything done or any arrangement entered into before 2 December 1998, to make it clear that it will not apply to the exercise of an option provided for under the legislation, and to ensure that it applies to where the tax benefit is obtained in the principal effective arrangements and not simply in a principal effect.

We have looked at the anti-avoidance provision issue again and proposed a range of amendments. I would have to seek advice from the Taxation Institute as whether they are completely happy with what we have proposed. This is an example of where the government has listened to the concerns which were brought to the government's attention and has proposed an amendment.

talk.start.para: —I would be very interested to know because, on the evidence given to me, it is unlikely that you would get an affirmative response from the Taxation Institute on the anti-avoidance legislation, but that remains to be seen. This is not the time and I do not intend now to debate in detail the merits of that legislation. But since you have mentioned it in some detail, let me observe in passing that the amendments which you propose to make will weaken the anti-avoidance legislation and will enable a coach-and-four to be driven through the anti-avoidance mechanisms This, I would have to say, goes to one of the principal points raised in this entire debate: that tax reform, if that be the enterprise we are embarked on, should be about preventing avoidance of taxation obligations.

speech.para: There is a strong debate in Australia, and rightfully—my party has subscribed to it very powerfully—that tax cheats should be stopped and that people ought to pay their full rate. If they did pay their full rate, there would be less tax levied on the rest of us who are honest taxpayers. The provisions to which you have referred I note now—and we will debate this when it comes up at the relevant time—weaken the anti-avoidance provisions in these bills. Frankly, I think that is a disgraceful step and I will deal with it appropriately. It is also a reason why I think it is very unlikely that the Taxation Institute of Australia would necessarily give you a thumbs up on those changes, but that remains to be seen.

To take you one step further, you say that some of the measures raised by the Taxation Institute have been met. You may wish to take this question on notice. Would you please indicate which ones, in the eight pages of amendments which they have proposed to this legislation, have been meet and which ones remain at large? With whom in the government did the Taxation Institute confer and who in the government made the decision to exclude those ones that have not been adopted? I ask this for information purposes, Minister, because I do not think that this chamber should turn its back on professional and expert advice by bodies such as the Taxation Institute.

I go to one other matter associated with their submission and turn to the Hansard. I apologise to Senator Harradine, who is in the chamber, because I am going to quote a line of questioning which he undertook of the Taxation Institute when they were before the inquiry. This appears in the Hansard of the select committee inquiry on Thursday, 4 March. Senator Harradine comments on an answer which was given and then turns to this question:
The other question that I have is on the issue of anti-avoidance, section 165.55 in the legislation, which states:
For the purposes of making a declaration under this Subdivision, the Commissioner may:
(a) treat a particularly event that actually happened as not having happened . . .
Further down on that page, if I may put it in these terms, Senator Harradine hits his stride and says:
To a layman, to provide a power to, as the act says—
he quotes it in full, and I will do so now—
(a) treat a particular event that actually happened as not having happened; and
(b) treat a particular event that did not actually happen as having happened and, if appropriate, treat the event as:
(i) having happened at a particular time—
and furthermore—
(c) treat a particular event that actually happened as:
(i) having happened at a time different from the time that it actually happened; or
(ii) having involved particular action by a particular entity (whether or not the event actually involved any action by that entity).
That is the end of the quote from the bill. Senator Harradine continues:
seems to me to provide the Taxation Commissioner with power that even God does not have. God cannot act in the contradictory manner, can he?
Mr Cooper from the Taxation Institute then said:
Our conclusion is that the draftsman at the time must have just finished reading Alice in Wonderland.
Minister, can you explain what the foregoing quotes from the bill mean?

talk.start.para: —I was under the impression when you raised your questions you were worried that the measures that we had proposed weakened the position and you were opposed to that. I think the Hansard will show you that you have argued both sides of the case. You wanted us to accept the proposals of the TIA, which—if I can bring it together—are, I suspect, that they felt that the anti-avoidance provision was too onerous. Then you attacked us for having, in your terms, weakened the provision. We do not accept that. The Hansard would, I think, show that you seem to have argued both sides of the case.

speech.para: You read out a clause of the bill and I will provide you with a few brief words on what that clause means. The particular clause you read out allows a power of reconstruction so that the commissioner can compare the scheme with a legitimate arrangement. It is essentially the same as part 4A, the general anti-avoidance provision.

talk.start.para: —If my questions were attacking you, Minister, they were attacking you on the basis of you not being able to decisively inform this chamber as to whether the government is intending to bring forward further amendments to its own legislation that it so urgently pushed through the House of Representatives before Christmas with the guillotine and to which now it has 128 amendments in this chamber. Certainly in the press—and I accept your answer that the press is not always an honest or an adequate purveyor of true information—they are reporting that senior government figures are saying there are further amendments. If I was attacking you at all—which I did not think I was; I thought I was just making the observation—for this debate in this chamber to mean very much, we need to see the entire position of the government displayed before us, including all of the amendments that the government is intending to make, and not have a situation in which the government at some other time in the future, when we have dealt with particular clauses, wants to come back and amend them again.

speech.para: My reference to the Taxation Institute was that here is a body of professional opinion, learned in this subject, suggesting changes to the tax act. I think it is important for us to know from you why you accepted some particular changes from them and why you rejected others.

The other matter that you mentioned—before I turn to the question that I have just read out—was the anti-avoidance measures. I think the anti-avoidance amendments you have proposed to this chamber weaken the protection of Australian taxpayers at large from tax avoiders. If they were carried it would be a diminution of power in the bill you have before us and that would be a sad event. I am not proposing to debate that in great detail now. When we come to that we will have an opportunity to do so.

My reason for having read this extended quotation to you is that the Taxation Institute, a learned body of august men and women expert in these matters, say in response to a rather pointed question, `Our conclusion is that the draftsmen at the time must have just finished reading Alice in Wonderland.' While it is, as I understand, related to the powers of the Tax Commissioner that you refer to, this is indeed quite a large expression of discretion on behalf of the Tax Commissioner—almost an unfettered one. If a tax professional organisation such as the Taxation Institute of Australia says this is Alice in Wonderland stuff, do you defend all of this? If Senator Harradine, for one, thinks that this is powers greater than reside in the Almighty, do you still defend this or are you considering putting any amendments to this provision in any way?

talk.start.para: —Senator, you have raised quite a range of questions in that contribution. Let me make it clear that this government is very opposed to tax cheats and you would be aware yourself that, when we have had debates in this chamber, we have brought in a raft of bills and clauses which cut down on tax avoidance schemes. I think that we have moved exceedingly firmly to close loopholes which we perceived occurred in the act. We believe that we have a fine record of dealing with tax avoidance. There was one, I think, where you and I differed, particularly the issue of R&D syndicates, where you were very critical of the government closing down that particular loophole.

speech.para: I took what you were saying. I understand that this will come back into the major debate; we will have major debate on this as this clause comes before the chamber. But I understood that initially when you spoke you were supportive of the anti-avoidance provision that was in the act. You then seemed to be supportive of the TIA's position, which again, by your terms, seems to have weakened the position. I will examine the Hansard very carefully, but I feel you have been arguing on both sides of the issue there. We believe that we do need a strong anti-avoidance measure and the government does not make any apology for that. I think that the measure that we have put in is a responsible measure and we believe that it is an important part of the bill.

In relation to the TIA there are a number of issues you asked me about which I said I would take on notice. I think that we will provide you with a response on the measures that have been picked up. That will give you a guide on the things which we felt it was sensible to make some adjustment on. As to the individuals concerned, it is most unlikely that the government would provide you with the information on that. That is probably not relevant to the decisions that are made. The government takes advice and ultimately the government is responsible, whether it accepts that particular advice or not. So I do not think there is any need to draw the names of individuals into this particular issue.

Again, you went back to the issue of whether there would be other amendments brought forward. In the normal course of debate, there may well be some issues which are raised in this chamber. As I said, we are entering into this debate. The government's position is well known. But if there is a need to finetune the bill, as we have done before, that may occur again. As I said, I do not rule it in and I do not rule it out. We will be listening very carefully to the debate in this chamber, as you would expect us to do.

talk.start.para: —Perhaps we should take the points one at a time. Let us settle this point. I think that the amendments on anti-avoidance that you propose—which we now seem to be debating, which I was not intending to do—make avoidance easier, not harder. You seem to be saying that the tax institute advised you to do that and you have accepted their advice. I am questioning you as to whether that is in fact true. Did they advise you to do this? I do not see that advice in the document they supplied to the Senate select committee. Are you defending the change in those provisions because the tax institute advised you or not? That is the first part and perhaps I should pause for answer on that.

—No, I am not defending the Taxation Institute on that ground. The government takes advice from a wide range of sources. There was the general issue of whether we had examined the positions put forward by the Taxation Institute. The advice I have is that we did. They raised some issues, and I think I was very careful to point out that I am not saying that they would sign on to all of the amendments we made. I make no claim to that whatsoever. But the institute did raise some issues. You asked me to be more specific in relation to a number of other things. If you put them on notice, I will respond to them as speedily as possible. I hope that by next Tuesday we can give you a response to them.

speech.para: You do not want to set up an unreasonable hurdle. I think we have been very straightforward with the legislation. The general package has been out since last August, and the legislation has been before the public gaze since December. The Senate committees have gone through the legislation with a fine-toothcomb. The government have continued to carry out consultations with people who have wished to come and see them. I have seen a range of people and I guess everyone in this chamber has been approached by groups putting forward views. Indeed, I think some of the debate that we are having relates to whether we except those views at all or in part. As the debate comes on, the positions of various people and parties will be revealed. With major tax bills, and any other major bills, it is inevitable that during the debate issues will be raised. The government will always look seriously at the issues raised.

talk.start.para: —I do not want to set up unreasonable hurdles, I want to get to the nub of the debate. You say that the government's position is well known and has been known since October. The bills that we are now considering came forward in December, so we only saw what your legislative changes were in December, and we now have some amendments. All I want to do here, and it is nothing more complicated than this, is find out whether this is the extent of your amendments, whether this is the extent of what you are asking the Senate to consider or whether you have further amendments elsewhere. You are unable to confirm or deny whether there will be further amendments. I then come to those questions that I have asked. I still do not have an answer for the last one, relating to section 165-55 of the legislation. It says:

speech.para: For the purposes of making a declaration under this Subdivision, the Commissioner may:
(a) treat a particular event that actually happened as not having happened;

The Taxation Institute says that the draftsman must have been reading Alice in Wonderland when he or she wrote those words. You are not in a position to say whether there are any further amendments, but is the government examining that matter? Does it have it under consideration? Is it the position that it has not decided whether it should tighten those provisions in any way? Are we therefore to expect that when it does make a decision on that, we will hear further? Or is this the proposition that you will be putting to this chamber for us to vote on, when we come to it, and you do not have under review any provisions to amend the section?

talk.start.para: —I am not aware of any further amendments that the government is proposing to this section.
—Have you seen Senator Harradine?
—Senator Conroy, the debate was proceeding quite well before you arrived in the chamber. It took about one minute and then you started. I thought you might restrain yourself for at least two minutes.
—Minister, could you address the chair and ignore the interjection. It would make life easier.

—Yes, I will certainly do that. But it may help matters if, when the interjection occurs, you also make a ruling. As I said, Senator Cook, there is a debate occurring and undoubtedly issues will be raised. On the specific matter you raised, I am not aware of any further amendments that the government will be seeking to move to that clause.
—I have here a press release from the Treasurer, dated 22 January 1999. It is headed `Treasury portfolio—allocation of ministerial functions'. It says:

speech.para: ASSISTANT TREASURER
1. Taxation.
. detailed design of taxation laws.

The reason I ask you whether there is anything out there in the wings is that, according to the Treasurer, you are the person who has, under your responsibilities, the obligation to preside over the detailed design of our taxation laws. You would know if there are any changes, would you not? You would have the ability to rule in or rule out future changes. Are there matters not yet resolved—still under active consideration—which may result in further amendments to this legislation?

talk.start.para: —Thank you for reading out the press release. On the broad policy issues, I think you will find that the Treasurer takes an active and interested role. On those broader issues, you would understand that the Treasurer plays the key role. I responded to your question when I said that, in relation to the issue you asked me about tax avoidance, the government is not considering, at this stage, any further changes to that clause. I think that provides the answer you wanted.

speech.para: On the general issue, I brought forward to the chamber the amendments that the government has felt it needed to finetune the legislation, reflecting the consultation which we have had. I also said, with respect to further amendments, that I do not rule any in or out. At this stage, these are the ones of which I am aware.

talk.start.para: —Let me go back to the press release. It says:

speech.para: The Assistant Treasurer and the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation will have responsibilities in the development, implementation and administration of the policies in the areas set out below.
ASSISTANT TREASURER
1. Taxation
. detailed design of taxation laws.

On that basis, Assistant Treasurer, one of the submissions to the inquiry was from the Housing Industry Association of Australia. The Housing Industry Association, if I can summarise their comment, regarded the compensation provisions for home buyers in these bills as not adequate. The HIA's fair compensation has three elements: the first one is the exemption of stamp duty for first home buyers under the First Home Owners Scheme; the second one is a targeted GST rebate on new houses and renovations; and the third one is a mechanism to link the GST compensation to contracted work in the formal economy. They said they were urging the government to accept those changes.

They said that they were not in the cart of supporting the government's legislation. But they were not out of the cart either; they were in the `it depends' category. It depended on whether or not the government would remedy its legislation in terms of compensation for home owners as to whether or not the HIA would support your legislation.

I make those remarks—they are not germane to my question—as an observation on the way through, because I think your answers are prone to trying to indicate whether submissions support the concept of a broadly based consumption tax or not. They are in the `it depends' category. Dr Silberberg, speaking on behalf of the Housing Industry Association of Australia, said in his submissions to the inquiry:

The proposition that HIA puts to this committee, and has put to the government, we consider to be a very fair and reasonable one. We are not asking for additional GST revenue to be forgone. It is primarily a cost neutral set of proposals. Those proposals do not disadvantage the national economy. Indeed, they improve them. In response to your question, I would have to say that HIA could not support the tax package in its entirety were the compensation arrangements for the housing sector not to be amended.

Given that your responsibility is the detailed design of tax laws, and accepting your answer, which obviously is true, that the Treasurer himself has an engaged interest in this matter, is the government still considering or has it ruled out entirely any changes to any amendments that we would wish to bring forward that would reflect the concern of the Housing Industry Association that the tax package is not fair to home buyers and to those in the housing industry? Has it ruled that out or in, or is it still considering it? What is the situation?

talk.start.para: —The amendments which the government has brought forward are the package of amendments which we think are appropriate to finetune the legislation, and I hope those amendments will be welcomed. We think that the compensation arrangements for first home buyers are fair and that we have put forward an appropriate proposal. We do not propose to make any changes to those amendments which have been brought forward. We would respectfully have to differ from the HIA on that issue.

speech.para: There has been a pretty extensive public debate, if I recall, almost from day one. I think the HIA had a pretty strong view on what they thought was appropriate compensation. The government has stated its position. We have heard the debate and we believe that our position as originally stated is a fair position. We are not proposing to amend that position in the amendments that have been brought forward.

talk.start.para: —I too, like Senator Cook, am concerned about the lack of clarity in what the minister has been able to inform the committee about. He does not know whether the government is going to bring any further amendments or not or, if he does know, he is certainly not going to inform the committee of that. He will neither rule in nor rule out any option that the government might have.

speech.para: There is an extraordinary lack of detail here. You would expect that, as the committee stage debate begins on such an important package of bills, we ought to be provided with that level of important information because we are expected to debate the detail of the package itself. The government appears to be unable to grapple with some of the detail of its own package. We have serious concerns, for example, about the veracity of the government's figures on the cumulative GST payout to the states, which quickly eroded this week—along with the Prime Minister's credibility on this very issue.

Let us cast our minds back to the Sunday program and to what is quickly becoming known as a very notorious interview that was conducted with the Prime Minister, where in a fireside chat on regional television he was caught out misquoting OECD figures and where he also claimed that the states would receive a handsome return from the GST of $20 billion per annum by the year 2010. The opposition quickly realised that the Prime Minister was going, yet again, into Billy McMahon mode. This was real Billy McMahon speak.

talk.start.para: —He hasn't got the ears for it, though.

—This is really Billy McMahon speak if ever I heard it: just quote any old figure at all that comes into your head. That is the Prime Minister's approach, the same as Billy McMahon's: any old figure that comes into your head, grab it out of thin air and quote it, particularly if it sounds like a really big figure, and hope you get away with it. The Prime Minister has not got away with it. The use of slippery figures became a hallmark of Mr McMahon's prime ministership, and I have drawn attention to the parallels between the prime ministership of Mr McMahon and Mr Howard before. I think this same approach really is starting to characterise Mr Howard's prime ministership as well.

speech.para: I think the Prime Minister is becoming arrogant. He is becoming sloppy when it comes to his duty to explain the details of this package to the Australian people. We picked up this $20 billion gaffe about the detail of the tax package in question time in the Senate on Tuesday of this week. Who could forget the embarrassment and humiliation of Senator Alston? Who could forget his embarrassment in that question time on Tuesday, 20 April, when I asked him whether the Prime Minister was wrong on the Sunday program when he claimed additional revenue of $20 billion a year to the states or whether he was wrong last year when he claimed $25 billion over 10 years. You would think it was a simple enough question. The Prime Minister could not have been right on both occasions, and I think the opposition, the Senate and the Australian people are entitled to know whether either of those two figures were correct and which one it was.

What did Senator Alston eventually say in reply? Poor old Senator Alston. He struggled through question time, as I think everyone knows, and eventually he scrambled and scrabbled around and found a question time brief and hurriedly read it into the Hansard. He said this:

. . . on agreed Premiers Conference estimates, the states will gain around $1.8 billion in 2004-05 and around $2.9 billion in 2005-06. Thereafter, the annual gains will continue to grow as GST revenue grows. Even if the annual gains remained at $2.9 billion, by 2010 the states would be around $17 billion better off in cumulative terms. That sounds pretty much like $15 billion to $20 billion to me.

talk.start.para: —That is how he got the Telstra price wrong.
—I do not think he got very much right at all, Senator Murray. I know that you try to be objective, and you would probably acknowledge that that is the case.

speech.para: What Senator Alston did in question time was really let the cat out of the bag about the Prime Minister's continually sloppy use of figures. He almost swallowed when he used those three little words `in cumulative terms', because he knew that the Prime Minister had been found out again on the detail of the package. He was exposed again as sloppy, not across the detail, not able to quickly correct the record and, in fact, negligent in that regard.

Senator Alston let the cat out of the bag on that occasion. I suppose the opposition did not realise at the time that there were two cats in the bag. We quickly did, because he said also in his answer that the gains to the states by 2010 would mean they would be `around $17 billion better off'. So that meant that the original pie that the Prime Minister quoted last year of $25 billion had been cut by almost a third. We have since found out that the pie is even smaller, and I will talk about that in a moment.

Here we are at the commencement of the committee stage of the debate with Senator Cook asking reasonable, responsible and sensible questions about the government's intention in relation to amendments, and we have a government that is struggling already in the committee stage of the debate, proving time and again that it is struggling with the detail of its own tax package. I want to refer to what Mr Howard was asked this morning on the Neil Mitchell show in Melbourne. Mr Mitchell said:

Mr Howard, I've seen you describe this as a growth tax for the States. And I saw you, I think it was with Laurie Oakes the other day, saying it could grow to $15-$20 billion a year for the States. Is that right?
HOWARD: Well, the amount involved—it will grow to that figure. If I said a year then that was a slip.

talk.start.para: —Ha, ha! Big slip! A $20 billion slip!
—I understand that it was a very sotto voce slip on the Neil Mitchell program, Senator Sherry. He continued:

speech.para: If I said a year then that was a slip. It will grow to about $15-$20 [billion] perhaps a bit more, it's a bit hard to estimate. I've been told by the Treasury that by the year 2005 the States will be $2.9 billion better off than they would have been if the old system, that's the present system, had continued.
This interview went on, and I commend the transcript to interested senators. I quote Mr Mitchell again from a bit later in the interview:

The way I read this, the GST is not the main growth component of the tax. I mean, you talk about $25 billion, extrapolating $25 billion. Only $8 billion of that looks to be GST and the rest of it, on the figures I've seen, is this non-residential stamp duty.

HOWARD: I think we are looking at two separate sets of figures. I think we really are at cross purposes. I'm talking about the fact that once the GST is fully operative, once all the State taxes have been abolished, all of the revenue from the GST, that is the 10 per cent collected all around the country, all of that goes to the States.
MITCHELL: And it leaves them $3 billion . . .
HOWARD: By 2005 they'll be $3 billion better off than they are under the existing arrangement.
MITCHELL: Although they've wiped out all their other taxes? All the taxes . . .
HOWARD: They don't get the GST unless they do that.

I commend this transcript to honourable senators, because Mr Howard again has been clearly caught out on the detail of his own tax package. That is becoming the pattern. What we are seeing again in this committee stage today is a government unwilling even to provide information to the committee as to whether it will be coming forward with further amendments at a later stage.

talk.start.para: —Why didn't Alston own up?

—I do not know why Senator Alston did not own up; I think he has had a pretty bad week, Senator Sherry, and I think you would acknowledge that that is the case. It is humiliating to have to come into the Senate and correct the record, but ministers are required to do that and, of course, Senator Alston should have.

speech.para: You only get the $17 billion to $20 billion if you keep one of the state taxes the government has been promising to cut since the launch of the ANTS package. You have got to ask, `Which tax is it?' And the only one that comes within the ambit of $17 billion by the year 2010 is the business conveyancing tax—stamp duty on the transfer of a business. Without this tax, the flow-on from the GST alone to the states by the year 2010 will be only $8 billion—less than a third of the Prime Minister's first proposal of a year ago and less than half of Senator Alston's correction on Tuesday.

I think we are now in the situation where the Prime Minister has got to explain himself and where the government has got to explain itself on this issue. The great GST growth tax is shrinking rapidly: $25 billion to $17 billion, to $8 billion now by the year 2010. Mr Howard has problems in reading tables. He showed that with the OECD tables, which I thought was very effectively exposed by Senator Cook in question time earlier this week. But here is another table that I would commend that senators read. He has read a total from a table of net budget impact from the year 2005-06 but failed to read from the appropriate table—final budget impact after abolition of non-residential conveyance duty when sufficient surplus available. He has misread another table.

Some of my colleagues might not agree with this, but I think the Senate has a lot to thank Senator Alston for. State premiers—Mr Kennett and others—probably have a lot to thank Senator Alston for. After all, Senator Alston has been singularly responsible for exposing this further fraudulent instalment of this massive fraud of a tax package. I have to say this, Mr Temporary Chairman—and I am sure my colleagues in the opposition would agree: this only stiffens Labor's resolve to vote this dodgy and fraudulent package down.

talk.start.para: —In contrast to Senator Faulkner, who seemed to come in quite late, I actually thought the debate got off quite well. He misquoted me, as he often does. The general line that Senator Cook was running was would there be other amendments and would I rule out any further amendments? I said, `The amendments we have brought in reflect the consultations that the government has had. They finetune the bill and they are amendments which we think are appropriate.' As to any future amendments, I said, `I simply cannot rule that in or out. We will listen to the debate as it proceeds.'

speech.para: I did ask Senator Cook whether he could rule in or rule out any other Labor amendments because, as I understood the press, there was some confusion about whether Labor were going to be moving amendments or not. What in fact happened was that we received some Labor amendments this morning. I do not dispute that—Labor are perfectly entitled to move amendments. All I am saying is that it seemed to be in contrast, Senator Cook, to what I understood was being said in the press by Labor spokesmen. Perhaps the press got that wrong.

But then I asked, `Will Labor be moving any further amendments?' and I did not receive any answer to that. I think, probably, that Senator Cook will be listening to the debate as it proceeds, and the Labor Party will then make judgments about whether they wish to move further amendments or not. That is the way debate has always proceeded in this chamber. It was a somewhat courteous question from Senator Cook. I hope that, if I did not give him entirely the comfort that he sought, it was a somewhat courteous response.

Then in comes Senator Faulkner and bangs the table, saying how hopeless the rest of the world is apart from Senator Faulkner. For the record, Senator Faulkner was the only Labor environment minister to actually lose the environment vote. I was personally very grateful to Senator Faulkner for that. I cannot say that I have an affectionate spot for Senator Faulkner, but I was grateful for that major blunder. Then, of course, we got a torrent of abuse about Senator Alston this and Senator Alston that, then a bit on Senator Kemp and a bit on the Prime Minister—blah, blah, blah—which went on for 20 minutes. If Senator Faulkner or anyone else wants to have a slanging match, we can always have one. But it seems to me we have had plenty of debates on the general issues on the bill. I think this is an important bill and, to my mind, it should be considered very seriously by this Senate chamber.

The premiers walked away from the Premiers Conference feeling very pleased with the deal they had received under the package. They were very pleased with the response that the government had made. All the premiers walked away thinking this was an historic occasion, very happy with the package that had gone through. The government was not unhappy to receive the supportive comments that Labor premiers made about the package, and rightly so. Why wouldn't we be?

talk.start.para: —The question put to me directly by the Assistant Treasurer is: has Labor put down all of its amendments to these bills or are there more to come? That was the question. I seek a nod in the affirmative from the Assistant Treasurer, and I receive one. That is the question. The answer to the question is: yes, we have. We have put down all of our amendments. They were in the chamber and distributed before we commenced the debate on these bills.

speech.para: The one amendment that applies to the bill that is before the chair now is an amendment in which Labor wants the legislation changed so that the price of the GST is shown on the retail docket of consumers—that is, when people at the checkout receive their final docket, they will have the price of the good, how much tax they will pay and the total amount they will pay shown on that docket. So they will know how much tax grab there is on one of the goods they have bought in a store, and when there is a service delivered they will know how much tax they are paying on that service when they were not previously taxed on that service. That is the only amendment and, when we come to it, I will move it. The answer is: we do not occupy the position of refusing to rule in or rule out further amendments to the bills now before us. All of our amendments are there and all of our amendments were put down before we started this debate.

talk.start.para: —I want to deal with the amendments issue, which is what we have been focused on since the beginning. Before I do so, I want to remark on the section 165 discussion that we just had. Whilst it is true that we should be very careful of weakening or making loose anti-avoidance compliance provisions and clauses, we also have to be careful of going the other way and having far too authoritarian and dictatorial conditions. One of the real worries we all have with section 165 is that it gives absolute and utter discretion on issues to the commissioner. The question is whether that is properly done. It reminded me, in the authoritarian sense, of something I heard from a South African brigadier in the South African police.

speech.para: In the apartheid era, the people you would have been very wary of and who could be pretty scary people were senior police officers in the South African police. See whether what I am going to quote to you sounds a little like this clause. In regard to some fairly nasty events in the Eastern Cape, this brigadier said, `I deny it is true, but I would deny it even if it wasn't true.' That is what nasty authoritarian people do. That is how they behave. We have to be a little careful with language like this which allows people in a regulatory situation to make a declaration that something that did not happen will happen or something that has not happened has happened. Part of the concern of the parliament should always be to protect the rights and liberties of its citizens.

Moving on from that issue, which was raised earlier by Senator Cook, I have two questions relevant to the line of questioning of Senator Cook. The first question is: are we likely to receive more bills which will influ ence the way in which we should view what is already before us? I am aware that in terms of the ANTS package, a new tax system package, there are still due bills on beer and spirits excise, for instance. But I would wish to know if there were new bills coming through which would alter the situation—matters that are relevant to the ANTS package as announced by the government. I know business tax reform is due, but that is over the horizon.

Coming back into the amendments arena, I am not overly concerned if the government have more amendments or less or Senator Cook has more amendments or less if they are not matters of substance. I think the real issue that concerns us is: are we likely to see amendments from government which address fundamental matters of substance? Let me explain what I mean by that. The view that is taken on the GST package and this first bill which is before us is profoundly affected by the view that the parliament takes of the income tax cuts and of the compensation package.

If the government were to contemplate, for instance, changing its income tax scales as an amendment or, for instance, adding hundreds of millions, maybe billions, of dollars to its compensation package because of the criticism which has come arising from the Senate inquiry and the conclusions of that inquiry and because of the comments by such people so close to the coalition as Dr Hewson, it could profoundly affect the way in which people regard the GST provision. Let us be extravagant. If compensation was boosted by $10 billion—I know that is not possible—everybody might suddenly say, `That makes a difference.' You appreciate the point I am making. If the government is going to come forward with those amendments, it would materially affect the way in which the provisions which affect the poor and disadvantaged in our society are looked at by some senators.

The other issue which would affect it is the compliance issue. I hope the states are listening to that, and I will come to that point directly. The second point of section 55 is this:
Laws imposing taxation, except laws imposing duties of customs or of excise, shall deal with one subject of taxation only;

And then it goes on to what happens with laws imposing duties of customs and excise. In respect of that last matter—one subject of taxation only—there does arise a question as to whether the GST bill is constitutional. Might I, first of all, refer to Jeffery Hodgins, whose excellent work Sales Tax in Australia —page 14—states:

When the original sales tax legislation was in the process of formulation in 1930, the opinion of eminent Counsel was that it would involve nine separate subjects of taxation. In order to comply with section 55 of the Constitution, therefore, it was enacted in nine consecutively numbered Assessment Acts each with a corresponding Rates Act.

Of course, in 1992, three imposition bills were used for the new sales tax, whether or not the drafters of those bills had considered the High Court case in 1992. Nevertheless, sales tax is a single-stage tax on goods only. By contrast, the GST is a multi-stage tax with refunds. The High Court's decision in the Mutual Pools case seems to indicate that the Commonwealth may not be able to make up a subject of taxation entirely as it pleases and that it cannot tax land and intellectual property, for example, under the one imposition act. That is one side of it.

I am indebted to the Parliamentary Library for advice on this particular aspect, and might I just indicate that this advice is in respect of A New Tax System (Commonwealth-State Financial Arrangements) Bill 1999, and reference is made to the case of Nott Bros & Co. Ltd v. Buckley. The advice that I am given says:
If Nott is followed, proposed subclause 10(1)—
of the Commonwealth-state financial arrangements bill—

being an important condition in changing the rate of GST, may be a law imposing taxation for the purposes of section 55 of the Constitution. In that case the other provisions in the Bill may have no effect. The other significant provisions in the Bill which may be invalidated are those dealing with changing the base of the GST, the distribution of the GST revenue to the States by way of grants and the appropriation made to effect the distributions.
The next point of the advice that has been given to me by the Parliamentary Library, the Economics, Commerce and Industrial Relations Group. It goes further and states on page 10:

Thus proposed subclause 10(1) of the Bill which provides `The rate of the GST, and the GST base, are not to be changed unless each State agrees to the change' could only give the States a veto power by a constitutional amendment following the procedure in section 128 of the Constitution.

The states currently do not have a veto power; under the Constitution they cannot have one. I believe the Parliamentary Library is pointing out that that could be done only by way of a constitutional amendment following the procedures under section 128 of the Constitution, unless the government is going to load the referendum with such a constitutional provision. The advice continues:
Until that process is gone through, that provision would be of no effect and the Commonwealth Parliament would be able to vary the rate and base of GST without the consent of the States.

Thus the provisions in proposed clause 10 , requiring the consent of the States to vary the rate of GST and the base of GST, would not be binding on the Commonwealth Parliament and there would be nothing to preclude the Commonwealth Parliament from unilaterally changing the rate of GST and the GST base.

Clearly, they are constitutional questions that need to be examined, and there are ways of dealing with them. But they have been raised. talk.start.para: —While the minister is seeking advice, I will indicate that I did not say that the GST legislation taxed, in the words of Senator Kemp, land and intellectual property. I said that the GST is a multistage tax, with refunds, and that the GST bill includes many disparate subjects of taxation, including land transfers, services, transfers of intangible property and restrictive covenants. —My understanding is that the fact that it is a multi-stage tax does not go to the core of the legal issue. Each is treated in isolation as a supply. —Although I shortly want to get back to the questions I was pursuing on the housing industry, Senator Harradine has raised an extremely important point. It is one that, since his speech on Wednesday, I have given some thought to. Perhaps I should make some remarks on this topic at this juncture. The issue that was raised by Senator Harradine in his speech at the second reading stage and which he has pursued today is whether the GST legislation is constitutionally valid. He raised the possibility that the legis lation may not comply with section 55 of the Constitution. Section 55 reads:

speech.para: Laws imposing taxation shall deal only with the imposition of taxation, and any provision therein dealing with any other matter shall be of no effect.

Laws imposing taxation, except laws imposing duties of customs or of excise, shall deal with one subject of taxation only; but laws imposing duties of customs shall deal with duties of customs only, and laws imposing duties of excise shall deal with duties of excise only.

As I understand the argument that Senator Harradine has put, the GST legislation—specifically the general imposition bill—might be in breach of the second paragraph of section 55 on the basis that it deals with more than one subject of taxation.

In order to better understand the role of section 55 of our Constitution, I think it is necessary to say a little about its history. Like all things, our history of this section originates in Britain. Before the middle of last century, the Westminster system placed no limitations on the power of the House of Lords to accept, reject or amend taxation legislation. The turning point came in 1860, with what became known as the Paper Duties Precedent. The Prime Minister was then Henry Palmerston and the Chancellor of the Exchequer, William Gladstone. Both were Tories—Gladstone did not join the Liberal Party until 1867. They ended up provoking a fight with the other house of parliament—that is, the House of Lords—over the issue of tax. One could say that there is some sort of ancient parallel with what is happening here.

Palmerston and Gladstone drafted three pieces of legislation—one which increased property taxes, one which increased stamp duties and a third which repealed the duties on paper. The Commons passed all three bills but the Lords rejected the Paper Duties Repeal Bill, thwarting the government's package. The response of the Commons was to pass a resolution to the effect that legislation imposing taxation `is justly regarded by this House'—that is the Commons—`with peculiar jealousy', thereby preventing the Lords from amending the legislation. Such resolutions have a peculiar force under the United Kingdom's constitutional system.

The Commons then re-presented their tax package—to increase property taxes, increase stamp duties and repeal paper duties—in a single bill. Unable to amend it, the Lords had to accept or reject all three measures together, and they were forced therefore in this case to accept them. The same principle applied in other British dominions and in the pre-Federation colonies. Arguably, it was justifiable in those cases. After all, upper houses were generally unelected. Unlike this Senate, they had no popular mandate. So it made some sense to limit their power to amend legislation emanating from the lower house.

When the founders of the Australian Constitution came to consider this problem, they strove to attain a better balance. Our Constitution entrenches one aspect of the Westminster system. Section 53 reads:
The Senate may not amend proposed laws imposing taxation, or proposed laws appropriating revenue or moneys for the ordinary annual services of the Government.

Incidentally, because of section 53, the Senate is confined to making `requests for amendments'. I note that what the vast majority of the media and those in this chamber have been calling `amendments' are in fact requests for amendments. The same applies for government `amendments'. Most of those are also requests.

But the House of Representatives cannot abuse section 53, as the Commons did to the Lords in 1860. Why? The answer lies in section 55. The Senate, unlike the Lords, is an elected chamber. The constitutional founders therefore put in place a protection, in the form of section 55, which ensures that the Senate should never find itself faced with a composite tax bill. Such a bill would be unconstitutional.

There was some debate in the Constitutional Conventions as to what form the prohibition in section 55 should take. At the Adelaide session, in 1897, George Reid, the then Premier of New South Wales, moved to insert the word `proposed' before `laws' in order to prevent the clause from affecting the validity of a law when passed. But the delegates present felt that this was more than a matter of ensuring harmonious relations between the houses. It went to the very role of the Senate. It was concluded that the Senate, if threatened by a composite tax bill which it could only accept or reject, should have the protection of the High Court of Australia. Reid's amendment was withdrawn. If the section 53 gun was held to its head, the Senate might pass a composite tax bill. But the High Court policeman would soon declare the law invalid under section 55. Invalid in part? No, invalid in full.

At the Melbourne session of the Constitutional Convention debates, Reid moved another amendment—you start to get the sense that he did not really like section 55. The effect of this amendment was that if a law contained more than one subject of taxation, the tax first in order of enactment should be valid. The amendment was defeated 27 votes to 15. Thus an act embodying a plurality of taxes would be absolutely and completely outside the power of the Constitution.

How has the second paragraph of section 55 been interpreted by the High Court? The key words are `one subject of taxation'. In Resch v. Federal Commissioner of Taxation (1942) 66 CLR 198 at 223, Justice Dixon expressed the view that section 55 had only a limited impact. Because of his concern with political relations, he stated it `must be taken as contemplating broad distinctions between possible subjects of taxation based on common understanding and general conceptions, rather than on any analytical or logical classification'. His Honour pointed out that the classification of taxes into categories was common amongst economists and lawyers. But he held that section 55 was not bound by such categories. It was, he found, for the legislature to choose its own subject matter, `fettered neither by existing nomenclature nor by categories that have been adopted for other purposes'.

The principle that the parliament can choose its own subject matter was repeated in State Chamber of Commerce and Industry v. The Commonwealth (1987) 163 CLR 329. At page 344, Chief Justice Mason and Justices Wilson, Dawson, Toohey and Gaudron held that the test is whether:
the subject matter which is dealt with as if it were a unit by parliament . . . can . . . be fairly regarded as a unit or whether it . . . consists of matters necessarily distinct and separate.
In applying that test:

the court will naturally give weight to parliament's understanding that its tax act deals with one subject of taxation [and will] not resolve such a question against the Parliament's understanding . . . unless the answer is clear.

So the High Court authorities are unequivocal on one point—if parliament thinks an act deals with `one subject of taxation', the court will usually agree. But this assumes that parliament speaks with one voice. In the cases I have referred to, both houses of parliament did speak with one voice. The Senate had not complained that a gun was being held to its head by the House of Representatives. The challenge simply arose because both houses had decided that it was convenient to put slightly different types of tax legislation in the one bill. As there was clearly no abuse of section 53, the High Court agreed with the parliament's view that the legislation dealt with only `one subject of taxation'.

But here, there is a strong argument that the government are abusing section 53. As they themselves have claimed, it is the biggest tax reform in Australia's history. We have just undertaken the biggest Senate inquiry in Australia's history to find out the truth about it. And yet the essence of the tax is locked up in one single piece of legislation— A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax) Bill 1998 . The Senate cannot amend the main provisions of that bill. It must take them or leave them.

What does the general imposition bill do? Let me run through its effects. It imposes tax in some way on: personal property—such as sales of food, clothing, books, over-the-counter medicines, shoes, flowers and cars; real property—such as sales of farmland or sales of land that is part of a business; intellectual property—such as sales of copyright in books, films or software, sales of trademarks and sales of patents; and services—such as rent of property for a business, swimming pool entry fees, lawyers' fees, domestic air tickets, theatre tickets, public transport, membership of organisations, sponsorships, sporting grants and body corporate fees.

If a challenge to this legislation comes before the High Court, how will `subject of taxation' be defined? Are taxes on real property and personal property different subjects of taxation? If so, this legislation is unconstitutional. Are taxes on tangible property and intangible property, such as intellectual property, different subjects of taxation? If so, this legislation is unconstitutional. Are taxes on goods and services different subjects of taxation? If so, this legislation is unconstitutional.

Senator Harradine asks whether this bill deals with more than one subject of taxation. My reply is that it might well do just that. And in case any future High Court seeks to assert that `parliament' was confident that the main GST bill dealt with just one subject of taxation, let me make it clear that that is not the view of at least 28 members of this house of parliament.

talk.start.para: —Senator Kemp, it may help if I add some remarks and then you could encapsulate a response. Minister, when you respond to the contributions by Senator Cook and indeed by Senator Harradine—I think these are matters which both have researched at length and do need a very considered response—I would like to know the following things, and I will deal with a number of matters fairly shortly: firstly, the Democrats were aware of this issue, as no doubt were the government and other political parties because we have all received letters from constituents and concerned citizens in this area.

speech.para: One way in which the High Court could look at this matter, if they chose to do so, would be not only how it was presented to parliament and in what form but also the way in which it was marketed, if you like—through the government advertising to the people, and paid for by taxpayers—because the way in which it was presented to the people may colour the view in which it is held. I would like to know if in your view that matters. I would like to know if the way in which it was dealt with during the election period as a new tax system—in other words, as a grouping of taxes across a wide area—and the way in which it is being presented to parliament matter in your view. One of the things which strikes me about the constitutional provision and the way in which we are dealing with this matter is that all the bills have been presented to us to be debated cognately—in other words, in one lump. They have not been presented to us either at the second reading stage or the committee stage, nor, obviously, at the third reading stage, to be voted on individually and discussed individually. So I would like to know whether you think that dealing with these matters cognately through the Senate makes a difference at all.

The other point I wish to have you respond to is that, if the Senate did pass these laws, they were then proclaimed, subsequently challenged and, for instance, the High Court's decision came down in, say, August 2000 and it was that the bills were unconstitutional, would the government be subject to liability? If business had incurred between $1.9 billion and $2.7 billion worth of expenditure to put in the GST hardware and software that is required to manage this new system, and if the High Court declared the laws to be unconstitutional, what would be the liability of the Commonwealth? So they are questions that I would need to have answered as well.

talk.start.para: —It is far from me to speculate on what may or may not be in the minds of High Court judges and what the High Court itself may do with particular issues or whether they would take account of some of the matters which you have raised. I would have thought it most unlikely, as a layman. As I said, what judges take into account is a matter for the judges to determine, but I would be surprised.

speech.para: This debate is interesting because Senator Cook has raised the application of section 55. My understanding, Senator, is that the High Court has consistently refused to give the expression `one subject of taxation' as used in section 55 any narrow or inflexible interpretation. I am not a lawyer, but as Senator Cook went through he cited a number of cases. One was Resch v. Federal Commission er of Taxation (1942) and, in particular, he quoted the judgment by Justice Dixon. He then cited another more recent case. Senator Cook may correct me if I am wrong, but I think he was referring to the State Chamber of Commerce and Industry v. the Commonwealth (1987).

The reason I raise that is that Senator Cook, I think, had to accept that in fact the very judgments he raised were actually judgments supporting the view of not taking any narrow or inflexible interpretation. I think that Senator Cook then arrived at the end piece of his argument and said that, effectively, despite those particular judgments and quotations—and you can recall the exchanges we had because I was following the advice and the judgment that Senator Cook had in hand—he thinks that something else may occur.

But, essentially, the way I take it, Senator Cook, is that the very judgments and decisions which you cited actually supported the government's position on this, which rather intrigued me. Senator Cook then said that that may be the case but, on the other hand, he did not think the government could take too much comfort from this because they will look at the fact that there are at least 28 people in the Senate who do not happen to agree. Senator Murray then raised a number of other issues which he thought might turn or influence the minds of judges. Senator Murray, I as a layman cannot reflect on what would turn the minds of judges.

So, in a sense, Senator Cook's argument basically supports the government's position because by applying the observations that I think he made it becomes pretty clear that the general imposition bill deals with one subject of taxation only. The GST is a broad-based indirect tax which taxes particular transactions between entities, and specifically it taxes the conferral of a benefit by an enterprise on another entity in exchange for a consideration. Upon the enactment it would be pretty clear that parliament believes that the imposition bill deals with one subject of taxation only.

In a sense, I was very curious about Senator Cook's argument because the briefing note I have contains exactly the same quotations to support the government's position. Then Senator Cook said, `Well, something else may have intervened and maybe the High Court will take another look at this position. Maybe it will take a look at what the Senate said.' Senator Murray said, `Well, maybe the High Court will take a look at the government advertising campaign.' I am not sure why it would do that, but that is what Senator Murray said. He also said that they may look at the overall tax package.

This brings me to my conclusion, which is, essentially, that the reasons that Senator Cook stated for 95 per cent of his argument give comfort to the position that the bills are constitutional. As I said earlier on in relation to some debate I had with Senator Harradine, the government is, of course, entirely mindful of the need to protect bills against constitutional challenge. Great effort is made to ensure that bills are constitutional. Let me assure the Senate that great effort has been made in this case, and that is why we believe the bills are constitutional.

That brings me to the final point about speculation. Senator Murray has asked me to speculate on what happens if such and such happens with the High Court and the decision means that these bills are not constitutional. Senator, I would not speculate on that because we believe the bills are constitutional.

talk.start.para: —To pursue the line of questioning I was putting, I think what has prompted real attention to this matter has been raised by Senator Harradine. Senator Harradine is sometimes somewhat jocularly referred to as the father of the Senate, but there is a real seriousness to that matter—that is, he has been here for 23 years. None of us regards Senator Harradine as being a flippant senator. He does not raise issues to be amusing or to be diversionary. He has researched this issue, he has raised it and it requires a serious response because it would be a serious matter, obviously, if something were to be subject to constitutional challenge.

However, once we get into committee it is also the government's job to reassure the Senate that it has been properly looked at by people with real constitutional law experience and that they have assessed all these matters. Even if you are unwilling to table the legal advice, we would need to know that appropriate legal advice of the most senior sort had been taken.

Let us move on from there and go back to the questions I was asking. The questions I was asking were not speculative at all. talk.start.para: —Senator, you have posed a number of questions. Let me make it clear: the government believes these bills are constitutional. These bills have been through the appropriate assessments to ensure that their drafting is constitutional, and the government's view is that they are.

speech.para: Senator Cook and I had a frank exchange of cases and, in fact, both the cases were the same and the quotes that we drew out of those cases were the same. The particular quotes that Senator Cook gave for the two cases were ones which I think he recognised at the end of his remarks supported the government's position, particularly the earlier case which quoted Justice Dixon.

Senator Cook then went on to speculate what may turn the minds of judges if someone decided to make a constitutional challenge. Senator Murray has asked me what would happen if there was a successful challenge. We do not believe there will be a successful challenge because we believe the bills are constitutional. If anyone wants to spend a lot of money taking these bills to the High Court, on the advice and on the way we have drafted these bills that would fail. I do not plan to speculate on a hypothetical case in this committee stage. You say it is not a hypothetical case; in my view it is a hypothetical case. I do not plan to speculate on that particular matter.

Equally, in relation to the matters that Senator Cook raised, I believe that a fair view of the Hansard will give comfort to the government's position rather than the position that Senator Cook put at the end of his remarks.
