talk.start.para: —I thought I should rise, since my words were being quoted and since I am the author of them, to say a little more on the matter lest my words be misconstrued.
—Never.

—Never, of course, Minister. That is like one of those never ever promises such as `There won't be a goods and services tax.' For anyone to think that words in this chamber have never been misconstrued is drawing a very long bow indeed.
—Have you ever misconstrued anything?

—Not in my case, I have not. But I am aware of other examples. Let me work my way through this. First of all, it is my understanding that what the government has offered Senator Harradine, who has raised this question, is a briefing on the matter from the relevant legal authority in the government—I assume that is the Attorney-General—so that the question of the constitutionality of these bills, at least the government's view of them, can be fully canvassed with Senator Harradine. There was an interjection, maybe from Senator Woodley, at that point asking can the chamber have that information because it is in this chamber that each of us as senators are equal. This is an important matter touching on whether these bills have power to proceed or not. It would be useful to get that briefing.

speech.para: On behalf of the Labor Party, I would like to ask: if it is the intention of the government—although I would ask that the government do this—not to do it, would we also be able to get a briefing from the Attorney on the same matters that Senator Harradine has raised on this matter? I imagine other parties would like that as well. I do not derogate from the point that Senator Woodley has raised that it would be appropriate for the chamber at large to get that briefing. But if the government is not going to do that, we would like it.

The second thing is that Senator Harradine in his remarks on Wednesday raised a series of questions for the government about the GST legislation. One of the questions was the question of constitutionality. It is a fundamental question as to whether this parliament has the power to enact this legislation at all. I expressed a view to this chamber a moment ago about that and, Minister, you have interpreted it for me. Thank you for your interpretation. But let me insist that, if people really want to know what I have said, they should read my remarks and concentrate on what I said.

I will repeat what I said at the conclusion of my remarks. If a challenge to this legislation comes before the High Court, how will `subject of taxation' be defined? Are taxes on real property and personal property different subjects of taxation? If so, this legislation is unconstitutional. Are taxes on tangible property and intangible property, such as intellectual property, different subjects of taxation? If so, this legislation is unconstitutional. Are taxes on goods and services different subjects of taxation? If so, this legislation is unconstitutional.

Senator Harradine asks whether this bill deals with more than one subject of taxation. My reply is that it may well do just that. And in case any future High Court seeks to assert that `parliament' was confident that the main GST bill dealt with just one subject of taxation, let me make it clear that that is not the view of at least 28 members of this house of parliament.

If I am asked to try to summarise that, I think there are real concerns here. Those real concerns hopefully can be addressed before we conclude our consideration of these bills. It has been suggested to me that it may even be necessary to do that in a committee forum from the Senate.

If we go back to the key words `subject of taxation', the title of this legislation is `A New Tax System'. I would regard it as likely—although like you, Senator Kemp, I am not a lawyer either—that anyone who would want to argue that these bills are a subject of taxation might want to point to the title `A New Tax System', which brings all of the legislation together. It points out the fact that this is not just a bill to amend the tax law but to create an entire new system embracing several forms of tax law.

I just put it on the record to bolster my remark that there may well be serious prob lems here, and I do not wipe the issue aside. I think the Senate has been assisted by this issue being ventilated, as it was on Wednesday by Senator Harradine. From the Labor Party's point of view, I wanted to get that on the record so that our concerns were clear.

talk.start.para: —Senator Cook, I do not think I misquoted you, because the quotations that you gave were, I thought, as I said before, very similar. You quoted from Resch v. the Federal Commissioner of Taxation and you quoted from the judgment by Justice Dixon, which concluded—and I think this is the exact quote:

speech.para: What is the subject matter of the tax may be gathered from a general consideration of the enactment or enactments in question, remembering, however, it is for the legislator to choose its own subject and that its choice is fettered neither by existing nomenclature nor by the categories that have been adopted for other purposes.

Then I think you referred to another judgment, the State Chamber of Commerce and Industry v. the Commonwealth in 1987. Again, you quoted from that. If my memory is correct, one of the quotes that you used was that `in applying the testate above', their Honours—and `their Honours' in this case are Mason, Wilson, Dawson, Toohey and Gaudron—said:

Although the court is bound to insist on compliance with the requirements of section 55 so that the section achieves its purpose enabling the Senate to confine its consideration in each case to a taxing statute dealing with a single subject of taxation, in applying the testate above the court will naturally give weight to the parliament's understanding that its tax act deals with one subject of taxation only. This is because the application of the test involves what is in substance a question of fact or judgment. The court would not resolve such a question against the parliament's understanding, with a consequence that the statute is constitutionally invalid unless the answer is clear.

Then I concluded from that. I think we were in blazing agreement on the quotations that we exchanged. In fact, we both quoted the same cases. I then went on to say that, in applying these observations to the present matter, we think it is clear that the general imposition bill deals with one subject of taxation only. I went on to say that the GST is a broad based indirect tax which taxes particular transactions between entities and, specifically, it taxes the conferral of a benefit by an enterprise on another entity in exchange for consideration. Upon the enactment of the bill it is our view that it will be manifest that the parliament believes that the imposition act deals with one subject of taxation only and, therefore, that is the position which I put.

Where we differ with your position, Senator Cook, and I do not seek to misquote you, is that you say that in looking at what is described as `the largest tax package in Australia's history'—and I have said that many times, so I do not quarrel with you on that—the judges might have a different view. I think that, in a way, there was another development of that argument with Senator Murray. He said that because of the way in which bill was presented to the public, and he mentioned the advertising campaign, the judges may take a different view.

talk.start.para: —I said, Minister, that you might have a problem with the title `a new tax system', which suggests more than one tax.

—The government has looked very closely at these issues, and I have quoted you a number of cases which I think give great comfort to the government's position, and they are the same cases which you quoted. But you said that, despite these cases, despite what has been previously decided, the judges might have their minds turned by other factors. So, in summary, you think that there are questions. I do not think you went quite so far as to say that you did not think the bills were unconstitutional; you said, I think, that there are questions. The government has great confidence that these bills are constitutional. If the government did not believe that, we would not have presented them to the parliament. We are aware of these particular questions.

speech.para: Senator Murray, I think, has gone a bit further and has asked me to speculate on what would happen if the bills were found to be unconstitutional. I am not going to speculate on a hypothetical case, because we believe the bills are constitutional. We would not have presented them to the parliament if we did not believe that was the case. Just to conclude, I believe the cases that both Senator Cook and I have used support the government's position and not the position that Senator Cook has put to the chamber.

talk.start.para: —I am still confused about what the minister is saying in this respect. I am not sure if he is actually saying he is going to seek any further advice. It seems to me that he is saying that conclusively the government believes it is right. I did hear him earlier in the debate offer a briefing to Senator Harradine, and at that point I interjected that I hoped the chamber would have the benefit of that.
—Yes, and that is what I said.

—Yes, I thought you would have, Senator Harradine. The point is that the government could have given Senator Harradine a briefing at any point, because he has raised this both as a question and in a speech in the second reading debate. I cannot understand why the government has not at this point brought a briefing into the chamber, because Senator Harradine gave plenty of notice of these questions, and they are fundamental to this debate.
—And tabled it.

—Yes. The reason I say that the time for any private briefings for any of us has passed is that the debate is now here in the chamber, and that is why the answers have to be given here in the chamber. Private briefings are just not applicable. I am sure that is what Senator Harradine's position would be. So that is the problem, Minister. I hope that you will take that away.

speech.para: There is another problem. I do not know if you said that you were not a lawyer; I am not sure what your profession is, Senator Kemp. But if you are not a lawyer and Senator Cook is not a lawyer, I would suggest that we ought not to be depending on either your interpretation or Senator Cook's interpretation. We really do need a constitutional lawyer to give us proper advice. I am not a lawyer either, nor am I a Scribe or a Pharisee, but I think it is critical that we have a constitutional lawyer come back and give this House the information that it needs.

talk.start.para: —Senator Margetts. Sorry, the Minister.
—Senator Woodley, I did not think you were a Pharisee, I have to say.
—Excuse me; I had the call, didn't I?
—I am easy if someone wants to speak. But you called me, Madam Chair.
—You were jumping, Minister. I presumed you wanted to answer the question.
—I do. I wanted to respond to—
—It is on the same issue. I think it would be better if you answered all of them, not just one at a time.

—That is actually not the case, because there are complex questions which are appropriately raised by every senator. I will make that judgment, Senator Margetts, but it seems to me that if a senator speaks for 10 to 15 minutes and raises a number of issues, they are better dealt with at the time if I can. If we can save time by dealing with them all together, let me say that I would be the first person to do that.
—Madam Chair, on a point of order: if I have got the call, then the minister does not just stand and overrule it. I was actually called to speak.
—Sorry, Senator Margetts; I did call Senator Kemp.
—You actually called me first, Madam Chair.

—But my attention was drawn to the fact that the minister was on his feet so I called him. He is giving his answer that you may or may not agree with. I will call you next and then I intend to call Senator Sherry because he is also jumping, I think, on this issue.
—As am I, on the same issue.
—I think there are a number of questions that people want to raise about this issue, and the minister is choosing to individually answer them.
—As the senator is so keen and enthusiastic to make a contribution, I would be very pleased to hear what she has to say.

—I have actually been involved in quite lengthy committee stage debates on a number of very important and complex bills so far, and I have found that it works better if a number of people make their contribution on a complex issue and the debate is not interrupted by the minister answering each one separately.
—I am not responsible for whether the minister jumps or not, I am sorry.

—Certainly. However, I wanted to simply add that I have also sought advice from a constitutional lawyer, as have many people in this chamber, and I would share the concerns that have been expressed by Senator Harradine, Senator Cook and the Democrats on this issue. We are going to be involved in a very complex range of debates on a whole lot of issues. The government is very concerned about wasting time, and it would be an entire waste of time if what we find in the end is that the bills are not worth a cracker. I do not think they are worth much of a cracker anyway but, if we are forced into this process of going through bills which can clearly be knocked out holus-bolus on constitutionality, it is a waste of everybody's time.

speech.para: I simply wanted to add that the Greens (WA) share the concern and are also seeking advice. The advice so far is that it certainly ought to be looked at—not just for a political debate, but seriously looked at in terms of its constitutionality. If necessary, it needs to be changed so that it is quite clear we are not going to be simply required to waste our time and taxpayers' money to debate a bill which will be thrown out in the High Court.

talk.start.para: —I have stated this four or five times but let me repeat it: the government believes that these bills are constitutional. We would not have brought them into this chamber if there was some doubt. We have had quite an extensive debate on the various judgments and precedents which people are relying on, and the government above all does not wish to waste the time of this chamber. We wish to ensure that these bills have speedy passage. Let me assure you that the government is very mindful when bringing any legislation before the parliament to make sure it is constitutional, and we believe this is. I have quoted a number of cases in my remarks which I believe make it very clear and provide the precedents which certainly support the government's position.

speech.para: Senator Woodley raised the point that he believes the briefing should be here; in a sense, this is what we are currently having. This debate has gone on a bit further than I would have predicted but, nonetheless, there has been an extensive debate. There has been a pretty frank exchange of precedents and court judgments which I believe have supported our position. It is up to this Senate chamber how long it wishes to continue; it is quite entitled to continue this debate if it wishes. To the extent I can assist and respond to questions and get further advice to the Senate, that is precisely what I will do.

What does happen is that sometimes senators have a particular interest in a topic which they feel they would like to obtain more information on, and the government is always happy to assist in that area. If Senator Harradine, Senator Cook, Senator Murray and Senator Margetts wish to continue the debate on the constitutionality of the legislation, that is entirely up to this chamber. I would think from what I have stated from the government's position, from what I have stated from the government's procedures and from what I have stated from the various judgments that the High Court has made, I believe you could come to the position which I have made clear—which is, we believe these bills are constitutional.

talk.start.para: —The matter I wanted to raise does not relate to constitutionality, so I am quite happy not to proceed. I do not see anyone else springing up, so I assume there are no further questions this afternoon on constitutionality. I have two matters, and we are only two or three minutes away from conclusion for this week. I am glad to say that, in this special week that we have had set aside for the GST debate, on Friday after lunch we have finally got to the bills. After much obstruction by the government, we have finally got to debate these GST bills. Our intention on the Labor side is to see these bills, hopefully, defeated.

speech.para: I have two issues. Firstly, while Senator Harradine and Senator Murray are in the chamber, I want to draw to the minister's attention an issue relating to the 128 amendments that he might be able to enlighten us on next week when we resume. The 128 amendments have been presented by you, despite assurances from you on behalf of the
government and despite assurances from Mr Costello, the Treasurer, and the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, that this package was fine, it did not need fixing or amending, et cetera.

Anyway, there are 128 amendments, and these amendments go to a wide range of issues. Briefly, they go to financial institutions, insurance, reimbursement of employees in respect of imported supplies, nursing homes, free medical aids, farm land sale and the GST, long-term accommodation, the sugar industry—and that is just to name a few of the issues to which these 128 amendments go. Why does the regulation impact statement say that they have a nil or negligible impact on revenue? Surely, if these are significant amendments responding to concerns, they must have some financial impact.
Progress reported.
